title_as_recorded: Collections of excerpts, including Liber scintillarum by Defensor of Ligugé
subject: http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008422|http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008422;http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1212060|http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008395
physical_description: Extent: 65 leaves : parchment ; 123 x 87 (102 x 73) mm bound to 130 x 92 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (modern parchment, i is pastedown) + 65 (parchment) + ii (modern parchment, ii is pastedown): 1¹² (wants 1-3) + 2¹² + 3¹⁴ + 4-6¹⁰|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner beginning with folio 2 (2-65).|Catchwords: Catchwords added by the first hand to the right of center on folios 9v, 21v, 35v, 45v, 55v.|Layout: Written in 30 long lines, below the top line. Ruled in lead. Pricking marks visible on outer margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by two hands in Gothic minuscule (hand 1: folios 1r-7v and catchwords; hand 2: folios 8r-64v).|Decoration: 2-line initials in red, with a few of the guide letters visible on the left margins (folios 1r-7v); sentence initials and paragraph marks highlighted in red; rubrics underlined in red; chapter numbers washed in yellow or green (?) which has since turned brown.|Binding: Modern. Bound in gray velvet over paper boards. The velvet is worn out but otherwise the binding is in good condition.|Origin: Probably written in the first half of fourteenth century in France.|Former shelfmark: MS X17|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS A17|In relatively good condition despite extensive water damage, especially on the lower part of the first quire. The recto side of the first leaf is soiled and worn; the last leaf of the first quire has tears along its inner margin, with minor loss of text. Occasional holes, tears and imperfections in parchment throughout. Heavily trimmed on the fore-edge, with loss of some of the marginal rubrics. Annotations and overwriting in a few places. Ink smear and erasures on the lower part of folios 64r and 65v.|Liber scintillarum in this manuscript does not contain either of the prologues found in other manuscripts or Chapter 32 "De doctoribus sive rectoribus" according to the modern edition (Defensoris Locogiacensis Monachi Liber Scintillarum. Corpus Christianorum Series Latina CCSL 117. Ed. Henri Rochais. Turnhout: Brepols, 1957). Chapter 32 also is not listed in the table of contents, and chapters 33-81, which are in the same order as the edition, are numbered 30-80. The text continues with no break from the end of Chapter 31 to the beginning of Chapter 33, which in this manuscript is Chapter 32.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. From the collection of Alphonse Labitte: his bookplate pasted on the front pastedown. Possible bookseller marks: inscribed in pencil "Defensor" in capital letters and "Saec. XIV 1" in upper margin and "MS 31" [?] in lower right corner on front pastedown; "F07/Ym" [?] in pencil on upper right and initial "R" in brown crayon in upper left corner on back pastedown.

author_as_recorded: Benedict, Saint, Abbot of Monte Cassino|‎Ponchier‏, Étienne‏,‎ 1446-1524
physical_description: Extent: 152 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 133 x 91 (91 x 58) mm bound to 145 x 93 mm +
note: Title from opening rubric of the table of contents on folio 8v: "Sensuit la table de la reigle et status des monasteres de vierges de lordre Sainct Benoist reformees au diocese de Paris distinguee par chappitres."|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (parchment, i is pastedown) + 152 (parchment) + iv (parchment, iv is pastedown): 1-19⁸.|Foliation: Three sets of modern foliation in pencil: in lower right corner (4-10), beginning with folio 3; in upper right corner (11-138), beginning with folio 10; at center in the lower margin (1-152). The description follows the foliation at center in the lower margin.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner on folios 8v, 72v, 80v, 104v, 112v, 136v, 144v.|Layout: Written in 23 long lines, below top line. Ruled in red ink, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on outer margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in Bâtarde.|Decoration: 4-line boxed initial P in gold on red and blue background; 3-line boxed initial E in blue and white with a flower on gold background; 1- to 2-line boxed initials in gold on alternating red and blue background at the beginning of chapters; paragraph marks in gold on alternating red and blue background; line fillers in gold on alternating red and blue background; sentence initials washed in yellow; rubrics in red; guide letters visible to the left of initials.|Binding: Early modern. Bound in full leather over thin wooden boards. Blind- and gold-tooling on both covers; blind-tooling on spine. Sewn on four sewing supports. All three edges gilded. Endbands in blue and cream. Binding is very worn and the front cover seems to have been completely detached and repaired.|Accompanying materials: A detached paper slip (93 x73 mm) that contains a list of five items in French in an early modern hand.|Origin: Probably written in Paris, France in the first quarter of the sixteenth century, after 1506.|Former shelfmark: MS X18|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS A18|In good condition. Minor imperfections on parchment. Interlinear additions in red (folios 151r-152v), adapting the Latin prayers into singular feminine forms.|La reigle et status des monasteres de vierges in this manuscript includes the "Status" in 92 chapters preceded by a prologue (folios 12v-119v) and followed by "Les ordonnances pour les freres" in 16 chapters, which is also preceded by a prologue (folios 119v-138r). To these are appended the copies of the following: the approbation and ratification of the Status signed on May 5, 1506 by "Stephanus Parisien[sis] ep[iscop]us," that is, Étienne‏ Ponchier (folios 138r-139r), the process of apostolical confirmation of the Status signed by Pierre Raoulin (folios 139r-147r), another approbation of the Status signed by Étienne‏ Ponchier and endorsed by others (folios 147r-149r). Folios 8v-12v includes a detailed table of contents for all these subitems.|The manuscript was owned in the sixteenth century by a Sister Blessed Hope, possibly from the Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés in Paris, France according to two ownership inscriptions in ink, possibly by the same hand: on the upper part of the recto of the front flyleaf "Soror Spes Benedicta a Sancto Germano" and in the lower margin of folio 1r "E[glise?] de St Germain." Early modern (late sixteenth or early seventeenth century?) inscription in ink on the upper part of the recto of the front flyleaf by an unidentified owner: "Caroli Berault doctoris theologi Sorbonici." Late eighteenth-century inscription in ink on the upper part of the front pastedown by an unnamed owner, mentioning another unnamed owner: "Règle des religieuses de l'abbaye de Chelles près Lagny. Ce manuscrit m'a été donné en 1791 par un administrateur du district de Lagny." Bookseller marks on the front and back pastedown and on the front and back flyleaves. Initial "R" in brown crayon in upper right corner on back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 134 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 123 x 84 (90-100 x 51-60) mm bound to 132 x 90 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript composite codex|Collation: iv (paper, i and ii are pastedowns) + 134 (parchment) + iv (paper, iii and iv are pastedowns): 1¹² (wants 1, 2, 11, 12) + 2¹² (wants 1, 11, 12) + 3¹² (wants 1, 2, 11, 12) + 4-6¹² + 7¹² (wants 1, 12) + 8¹² (wants 11, 12) + 9¹² (wants 3) + 10¹² (wants 11, 12) + 11-12¹² +13-14⁴. Several leaves (possibly quires) missing, especially from Part 3.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1-134); one stub between folios 8 and 9, and two stubs between folios 81 and 82 unnumbered.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchword in lower right corner on folio 92v.|Watermarks: Single watermark on the front flyleaves: partly reads "ERRA" in capital letters (only part of the watermark present; unidentified); single watermark on the back flyleaf and pastedown: partly reads "P//U CAR//AÑA P?//T? CA" surmounted by sun in a circle (only part of the watermark present; very similar to CAHIP B1191).|Layout: Part 1: Written in 27 long lines, below top line, except for the table of contents (folios 1r-2r) which is written in two columns. Ruled in lead with full-length bounding lines. Part 2: Written in 28 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length vertical bounding lines and a full-length double horizontal bounding line in the upper margin. Part 3: Written in 22 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead and ink, with full-length single vertical and double horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on the outer margins throughout.|Script: Written by at least three hands (folios 1-81; 82-126; 127-134) in Gothica textualis.|Decoration: Part 1: 3-line puzzle initial D in red and blue with pen-flourished quarter bar border in red, blue and light blue extending from the initial on folio 2r; 2-line initials at the beginning of chapters in alternating blue with red penwork and red with light blue penwork; rubrics in red; chapter numbers in table of contents in red; initials in table of contents in alternating plain red and blue; sentence initials highlighted in red; most of the guide letters visible to the left of the initials. Part 2: 3- to 8-line puzzle initials M, C, D, P in red and blue with red, blue and light blue penwork on folios 82r, 102v, 105v, 107r respectively; 2- to 8-line initials at the beginning of chapters in alternating blue with red penwork and red with light blue penwork; rubrics in red; chapter numbers in table of contents in red; initials in table of contents in alternating plain red and blue; sentence initials highlighted in red; occasional paragraph marks in red; marginal additions by the scribe framed in red and blue; guide letters visible underneath the initials. Part 3: 2- to 3-line initials in plain red at the beginning of chapters; sentence initials washed in yellow; some rubrics in red; some rubrics underlined in red; paragraph marks in red; spaces left for 2-line initials at the beginning of chapters on folios 127r, 130r, 133r.|Binding: Modern. Parchment case binding over thin paper boards with laced-in tanned endbands, three of which are broken.|Origin: Probably written in France at the end of the thirteenth or the beginning of the fourteenth century. Part 3 might have been written slightly later than Parts 1 and 2.|Former shelfmark: MS X19|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS A19|MS A19 is a composite manuscript, consisting of three parts: Part 1 consists of folios 1-81, Part 2 folios 82-126 and Part 3 folios 127-134.|Dimensions of written area: Part 1: 100 x 60 mm; Part 2: 95 x 51 mm; Part 3: 90 x 53 mm|Liber scintillarum in this manuscript does not contain either of the prologues found in other manuscripts according to the modern edition (Defensoris Locogiacensis Monachi Liber Scintillarum. Corpus Christianorum Series Latina CCSL 117. Ed. Henri Rochais. Turnhout: Brepols, 1957). Also, the order of the chapters is different in the manuscript; they are found in the following order according to the numbering of the chapters in the modern edition: 1-7, 11-31, 8-10, 32-52, 55-58, 53-54, 59-81.|In relatively good condition despite missing and damaged leaves. Minor imperfections on parchment and signs of early repairs. All three parts heavily trimmed, probably at the same time, with loss of marginal annotations. Pen trials in the lower margin of folios 125v-126r.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Bookseller marks on the front and back pastedown and on the first front flyleaf.

note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (modern paper, i-iii are pastedowns) + 25 (parchment) + iv (modern paper, ii-iv are pastedowns): 1¹⁰ (wants 10, possibly blank) + 2⁸ + 3⁸ (1 and 2 are singletons).|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1-25).|Layout: Written in 23 long lines, below top line. A round paper label adhered to tail of spine with handwritten number "51."|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the fourteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y123|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 6903|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS B17|In relatively good condition despite significant water damage that resulted in discoloration of parchment and loss of ink. Damaged parts of the text supplied as overwriting and interlinear additions by a modern hand on several folios. Rubrics inserted by a modern hand on folios 14v, 17r, 20r, 21r, 23r, 24r. Heavily and unevenly trimmed especially on the fore-edge.|The manuscript contains a selection of texts pertaning to the lives and miracles of Saint Vitus, Saint Modestus and Saint Crescentia and seems to be a unique compilation. The final part of the first text, beginning with "Ad ostendendum autem verifice quod in predicte loco," on folios 8v-9v is copied again at the end of the second text, on folios 25r-25v.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. From the collection of Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 6903). It is inscribed "Phillipps MSS 6903" in black ink on front pastedown. Listed as no. 6903 under "Ex Bibl. Miscellaneis" in The Phillipps Manuscripts. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. This manuscript was probably among those inherited; however, there is no known record of it in the subsequent sales from the Phillipps library. Possible bookseller marks in pencil on front pastedown: inscribed "Passio et Vitae. Italy. 14th cent." and a price in upper half and "a.21.14" in lower half. Unidentified signature in red crayon in lower half of front pastedown. Inscribed "R" in brown crayon in upper left corner on back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 131 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 150 x 108 (110 x 80) mm bound to 157 x 110 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex.|Collation: 131 (parchment, 1 and 2 are pastedowns)+ ii (parchment, i and ii are pastedowns): 1⁸ (wants 3-6) + 2⁸ (wants 3-6) + 3⁸ (wants 4, 5) + 4-7⁸ + 8⁸ (wants 2-8) + 9⁸ + 1 leaf after 8 + 10-11⁸ + 12⁸ (wants 5-8) + 13⁸ + 14⁸ (wants 7) + 15⁸ (wants 2) + 16⁸ + 17⁸ (wants 1) + 18⁸ + 19⁸ (wants 7-8) + 20⁸ (wants 5-8). Two quires of eight leaves missing after 8.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in lower right corner (1-5, 10, 12, 15, 20, 23, 30, 45, 50, 60, 61, 62, 70, 80, 90, 100, 106, 110, 113), incorrectly placed on the subsequent leaf beginning with number 50. Foliation supplied by cataloger and does not include pastedowns.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right on folios 2v, 6v, 20v, 36v, 44v, 53v, 70v, 89v, 96v, 111v, 119v, mostly trimmed.|Layout: Written in two columns of 27 lines, above top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length double vertical bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on upper, lower and outer margins on most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica textualis libraria.|Decoration: 3-line puzzle initials S, M, F in red and blue with pen-flourished quarter bar borders in red and blue extending from the initials on folios 12v, 45r, 113v respectively; 2- to 3-line initials in red with blue penwork and in blue with red penwork throughout; sentence initials highlighted in red; paragraph marks in alternating red and blue; rubrics in red; running titles in red and blue in upper margins, indicating book numbers; guide sentences for rubrics in upper and lower margins mostly visible.|Binding: Modern, probably mid-nineteenth to mid-twentieth century. Bound in light brown leather over thick paper boards. Blind-tooled dark brown leather covers, possibly from the heavily damaged older binding of the manuscript, which perhaps was dated to the sixteenth century, partly adhered over the light brown leather covers. Sewn on three alum-tawed split thongs.|Origin: Probably written in the Benelux countries in the first half of the fourteenth century.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS CB92.|In good condition except for missing and damaged leaves. Folios 2 and 38 are torn, with loss of text. Minor water damage on the head and the fore-edge. Minor imperfections and signs of early repairs on parchment, including evidence of repairs by sewing. Occasional contemporary corrections and marginal annotations, most of which are probably by the scribe. A few modern annotations, some of which are faded or erased. Manicules on folios 11v, 18v, 47r, 48v, 127v, 129v. Several pen trials and annotations on both pastedowns.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Inscribed in ink "1743 mengots [?]" in the lower margin on folio 28v and "J[o]han Combes" in the outer margin on folio 39r, probably by different hands.

former_owner_label: Thomas Thorpe|Samuel H. Putnam|Estelle Getz|Prediger (Schwäbisch Gmünd)
physical_description: Extent: 310 leaves : paper ; 311 x 212 (213-215 x 137-139) mm bound to 317 x 212 mm
note: Title from contemporary title (added later) on recto of front flyleaf: "Augustinus de Anchona super Matheum cum tabula in fine."|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (paper, i is pastedown) + 310 (paper, 310 is pastedown): 1-25¹² + 26¹² (wants 10, 11, possibly blank; 12 is pastedown).|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed, possibly by the scribe, 1-26 in the upper right corner of the first recto of each gathering.|Catchwords: Catchwords, most of which are underlined in red, in the lower right corner, to the right of the inner vertical bounding line on folios 12v, 24v, 36c, 48v, 60v, 72v, 84v, 96v, 108v, 120v, 132v, 144v, 156v, 168v, 180v, 192v, 204v, 216v, 228v, 240v, 252v, 264v, 276v, 288v, 300v.|Watermarks: Watermarks present (unidentified).|Layout: Written in two columns of 41-42 lines, below topline. Frame ruled in two columns in ink, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines.|Script: Written by Johannes Baldung in Gothic cursive.|Decoration: 3- to 7-line initials in plain red at the beginning of chapters; sentence initials highlighted in red; rubrics in red or underlined in red; running titles, most of which are highlighted in red, at center in lower margins on the recto side of leaves indicating chapter numbers; guide letters visible to the left of the initials.|Binding: Fifteenth century, possibly original. Bound in full alum-tawed leather over wooden boards, with four paired single sewing supports and two integral endbands at head and tail (Kapitalbünde, braided) made of cords laced through channels and adhered to the insides of both boards and secured with wooden pegs. Five transverse spine linings made of parchment adhered to the inside of each board. Full external bevels on the three edges of the boards. Blind-tooling featuring various floral and other figures on front and back cover. Evidence of two fore-edge clasps hinging from the back cover and catching onto two lipped catchplates nailed into the front board, with the straps and the lower clasp missing. Evidence of chain sites on the boards; all chain components are missing. Minor wear and bookworm damage. The binding is worn especially along the spine and around the corners; the front board is detached. Repurposed parchment text guard excised and offset onto the inside of back board.|Accompanying materials: Detached parchment text guard (300 x 63 mm), extracted from underneath the back pastedown in 1973 by William T. Mitchell.|Origin: Written by Johannes Baldung probably in Schwäbisch Gmünd, Germany and completed in 1460: "Ioh[ann]es Baldu[n]g. Deo gr[ati]as. 1460" -- colophon, folio 297va and "Deo gr[ati]as. 1460" -- colophon, folio 307vb.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E263|In relatively good condition except for the detaching front board and the first quire. Minor foxing on the leaves and bookworm damage, especially in the first quire. Flyleaves soiled with minor water damage. Minor bookworm damage throughout. Back pastedown cut from head to tail vertically and partly unadhered. Marginal annotations and manicules throughout, mostly by the scribe and mostly highlighted or underlined in red. Annotations in Greek on the back pastedown.|MS E263 contains continuous loose sewing guards in each gathering: the center-folds are supported by approximately 10 mm parchment strips. These parchment strips are all repurposed fragments, seemingly coming from multiple but contemporary manuscripts, and most contain texts (unidentified).|The front and back text guards of MS E263 are made up of repurposed parchment fragments. The front text guard is in situ and visible under the front pastedown, folded around the first gathering, with its text illegible. The back text guard, which was under the back pastedown and which was folded around the last gathering, was extracted after the acquisition of the manuscript by the University of Kansas, leaving offset onto the inside of the back board. The extracted text guard is now kept in a folder with the codex. The repurposed parchment used for the back text guard comes from the middle of a leaf, currently measuring 300 x 63 mm, and is probably dated to the ninth century. It contains an unidentified text, possibly a commentary on the Gospel of Matthew, with what was the upper side beginning with "//cum omni malicia in cor//". Written in Caroline minuscule, in 32 long lines, with sentence initials in alternating red and brown.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Dominican Monastery in Schwäbisch Gmünd, Germany (Dominikanerkloster Schwäbisch Gmünd), now converted into a cultural center, Prediger Kulturzentrum. Title and contemporary ownership inscription in ink by a contemporary hand in the upper half of the recto of the front flyleaf: "Conve[n]t[us] Gamu[n]dien[sis] ord[inis] p[re]d[icatorum] [1484?: erased]" and "Augustin[us] de Anchona sup[er] Matheu[m] cu[m] tabula i[n] fine." Ownership inscription in ink by a different contemporary hand on lower margin of folio 1r: "Iste liber p[er]tinet conventui Gamu[n]diensi ord[in]is fr[atru]m p[re]dicatoru[m]." The manuscript seems to have left Germany at the beginning of the nineteenth century and came into the possession of Thomas Thorpe, listed by him for sale in 1831 in London. Nineteenth-century? handwritten description of the manuscript pasted on the front pastedown, perhaps belonging to Thomas Thorpe. About a hundred years later, the manuscript was listed for sale in 1924 by the Anderson Galleries based in the United States together with the rest of the collection of Samuel H. Putnam. Within a decade, the manuscript was in the collection of Estelle Getz (neé: Estelle Kohn). Listed as no. 24 under "The Library of Mrs. Milton E. Getz, 1007 Beverly Drive, Beverly Hills, California" in the Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada. It was sold by Mrs. Getz through the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries in 1936. Description from American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Catalog 4278 (no. 52) cut and pasted on the lower half of the front flyleaf, along with another cut and pasted typeset description (unidentified). Other bookseller marks in pencil on front pastedown.

note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript composite codex.|Collation: i (parchment) + i (paper) + 235 (paper and parchment) + i (parchment): 1¹² + 1 leaf added before 1 + 2-6¹² + 7¹⁴ (wants 3, 10, 11, 14) + 8-18¹² + 19⁸ + 20¹². Only the outermost leaves of the first quire are parchment (folios 2 and 13).|Foliation: Two sets of foliation in upper right corner: contemporary foliation in ink, beginning with folio 2 and skipping one folio between 99 and 100 (i-cxl); modern foliation in pencil on folios 99r, 100r, 142r, 142v, 144r, 224r (100, 101, 142, 140, 142, 223). Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner on folios 13v, 25v, 37v, 49v, 61v, 73v, 83v, 95v.|Watermarks: Single watermark on the front flyleaf: a pot with a handle (only upper half of watermark is extant; probably similar to Briquet BR 12477); five watermarks in Part 1: a dragon (similar to Piccard PPO 10-2-898); a pair of keys in a circle (similar to Piccard DE2040-PO-121491); a two-headed eagle (very similar to Briquet BR 230); a swan or a duck? (unidentified); a triple mound surmounted by a cross (similar to Briquet BR 11709); two watermarks in Part 2: a pair of scales (similar to Piccard PPO 5-4-185); a coat of arms in a circle with a shield vertically divided into two (similar to Piccard DE2730-PO-24774).|Layout: Part 1: Written in 2 columns of 28-31 lines, above top line. Frame ruled in lead, with full-length bounding lines. Part 2: Written in 37-41 long lines, below top line. Frame ruled in lead, with full-length bounding lines, now mostly erased (folios 144r-224v); frame ruled in ink, with full-length bounding lines (folios 225r-228r); unruled (folios 228v-235v).|Script: Part 1: Written by at least three hands (folios 1r-1v; 2r-80r; 80v-142v) in Gothic cursive. Part 2: Written by Herman Appeldorn (folios 144r-225r) and two other hands (folios 225r-228v and 228v-235v) in Gothic cursive. The second hand (228v-235v) may also be that of Herman Appeldorn.|Decoration: Part 1: 2- to 8-line initials in plain red; sentence initials highlighted in red; phrases underlined in red; rubrics in red. Part 2: 2- to 3-line initials in plain red; paragraph marks in red; sentence initials highlighted in red; phrases underlined in red.|Binding: Contemporary, possibly original. Tacketed parchment case binding with an envelope flap extending from the right side of the cover which folds across the fore-edge and is fastened with a brass clasp at the front. Inscription in ink on upper left of the front cover: "G.xlii." Evidence of a title running from head to tail edge of the spine, now effaced. A rectangular paper label adhered to the head of spine with typeset letters OO." Spine creases are torn on the tail edge. Staining due to minor water damage.|Origin: Part 1: Probably written in Cologne, Germany around 1451 or shortly after. Part 2: Probably written in Trier and/or Cologne, Germany around the same time. Part 1 donated by Johann? Warendorppe and the manuscript bound in Cologne, likely sometime before Herman Appeldorn's death in 1473.|Former shelfmark: MS Y180|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 646|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C91|Related shelfmark: Cologne, Historisches Archiv der Stadt Köln, Best. 233 Kartäuser, Repertorien und Handschriften, Nr. 14|MS C91 is a composite manuscript, consisting of two parts: Part 1 consists of folios 1-145 and Part 2 folios 146-235.|The copy of the Homiliae quadraginta in evangelia libri duo by St. Gregory the Great in this manuscript does not include the Preface.|The first front flyleaf in parchment is repurposed with no older text remaining and contains a contemporary table of contents for the manuscript as well as a donation inscription for the first part: "Ex donation[n]e d[omi]ni Jo[?] Warendorppe p[ro]ve[n]it nobis h[ic] lib[er] quoad Omelias Gregorii."|The back flyleaf is a repurposed parchment leaf, cut approximately in half and tucked in sideways between folios 223 and 224. Measuring 142 x 206 mm, its dimensions are slightly smaller than the leaves in the rest of the bookblock. Written in two columns, with 32 lines remaining. It contains Epistola ad Galathas / Hugh of Saint-Cher [incomplete, chapter 2], beginning on what is now the verso side: "[incipit] p[er] nu[n]ciu[m] [con]cessit eis ap[osto]latu[m] genciu[m] ... i[n] h[oc] [e]n[im] q[uod] n[on] co[m[ed[it] c[a]rnes; [verso b] q[uam] e[r]g[o] s[ed] difficili[us] fuit uno pati ... [et] [est] [contra]dict[i]o t[antu]m voca[lis] int[er] eos; [recto a] Ypoc[ri]ta eice p[rimu]m trabe[m] de o[culo] t[uo] ... p[re]dicabit [e]n[im] sal[u]t[em] f[i]n[e] obs[er]va[ntia]; [recto b] q[uasi] de suo locuti s[un]t [et] i[ta] m[en]tiri... [explicit] i[n]t[e]ll[ec]tu[m] leg[is] [et] obs[er]vat[i]one lega[lium]." Item on the back flyleaf was identified by Mark Thakkar, University of St Andrews, United Kingdom, 2021.|In good condition. Part 1: deckle edges visible on the fore-edge; few contemporary corrections and annotations. Part 2: extensive contemporary annotations, deletions, insertions and corrections, mostly by the scribe, Herman Appeldorn.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Charterhouse of St Barbara in Cologne, Germany (Kölner Kartause). Sixteenth-century shelfmark of the library inscribed in ink on upper left of front cover: "G.xlii." Seventeenth-century label of the library adhered to head of spine: "OO." Listed as "OO 89" in the seventeenth-century shelflist of the library, Cologne, Historisches Archiv der Stadt Köln, Best. 233 Kartäuser, Repertorien und Handschriften, Nr. 14. After the dissolution of the Charterhouse of St Barbara in Cologne in 1794, some of the manuscripts in its library were sold. During these sales, some hundred and thirty-six manuscripts were acquired by Johann Matthias Heberle (Antiquargeschäft mit Auktionsanstalt Cologne) and then sold in 1821 to Leander van Ess (Johann Heinrich van Ess). MS C91 was one of these manuscripts. In 1824, Leander Van Ess sold the manuscripts along with others that formerly belonged to the Charterhouse of St Barbara to Sir Thomas Phillipps. It is inscribed "Phillipps MS 646" in ink at center on recto of first front flyleaf and in the lower margin of folio 2r. Listed as no. 646 under "Catalogus Bibliothecae Manuscriptorum Leandri van Ess, S. T. D." in The Phillipps Manuscripts. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. In 1910, the manuscript was sold by Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick to J. & J. Leighton in a Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge auction of Phillipps manuscripts. In 1912, the manuscript was purchased from J. & J. Leighton by Robert Ranshaw. Bookseller marks in pencil on inside of the front and back covers.

The manuscript was probably ruled in lead but there is no evidence of ruling.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic minuscule.|Decoration: 25-line initial I in green, dark blue, white and gold with red and blue flourishing on folio 7vb; 12-line zoomorphic initial L in blue, orange, green, black and gold with red flourishing on folio 1ra; 2- to 9-line initials in plain red or brown throughout; sentence initials highlighted in red; rubrics in red; running titles in red in upper margin; chapter numbers in red in Roman numerals on inner and outer margins.|Binding: Unbound.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the thirteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y211|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C105|In moderate condition with minor water damage throughout that has caused ink smears and transfers, as well as faded ink to a lesser extent. The inner edge of the last folio is damaged and partly torn, especially in the upper left corner, with minimal loss of text. Evidence of former repairs on the spine-folds of the bifolia. Both illuminated initials are worn. An enumerated list for memorizing the chapters of the Book of Matthew by a later medieval hand on the lower margin of folios 1r-1v, which begins "V[er]sus ad retine[n]du[m] i[n] memoria cap[itu]la." Few later medieval marginal annotations, perhaps by the same hand, including brackets on folios 2r, 2v, 3r, 3v and 4r. Manicule on folio 2v.|History of the manuscript is unknown.

physical_description: Extent: 233 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 230 x 145 (165-170 x 75) mm bound to 240 x 150 mm
note: Title from opening rubric of the preface on folio 3r: "Incipit prologus magistri Petri Riga in librum aurore."|Manuscript codex|Collation: i (paper, pastedown) + 233 (parchment) + ii (paper, ii is pastedown): 1⁴ + 2⁴ (wants 1 and 2) + 3⁴ + 4⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 5⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 6¹⁰ (3 and 8 are singletons) + 7⁸ (3 and 6 are singletons) + 8⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 9⁸ + 10¹⁰ +11¹² + 1 leaf after 10 + 12⁸ + 1 leaf after 3 + 13-14⁸ + 15⁶ + 1 leaf after 1 + 16⁸ + 17⁸ (5 and 7 are singletons) + 18⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 19-20⁸ + 21⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 22⁸ + 23⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 24² + 1 leaf after 1 + 25-27⁸ + 28⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 29⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 30⁸ (2 and 7 are singletons) + 31⁴ (wants 4).|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in lower right corner (1-233).|Signatures: Quires signed in ink at center on the verso of last folio of the following gatherings by the scribe: quires 4-6 signed b-d; quires 8-22 signed f-i, k-t, v; quires 24-26 signed x-z; quire 27 signed an unidentified sign.|Layout: Written in 31-35 long lines (until 70v), in 41-42 long lines (between 71r-139v), in 30-36 long lines (from 140r), above top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length double vertical and quadruple horizontal bounding lines, occasionally with full-length double vertical and double or triple horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on upper, lower and fore-edge margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in southern Gothica textualis.|Decoration: 11-line anthropomorphic initial O in red, green, tan, white and black, depicting Peter Riga, at the beginning of Preface on folio 3r; 7-line anthropomorphic initial V in red, yellow, tan and black at the beginning of "Liber Leviticus" on folio 56r; full-page initial P with interlaced strapwork in red, white, yellow and tan at the beginning of "Evangelium" on folio 137r; 6- to 11-line initials decorated with interlaced strapwork or lines and spirals on folios 31v, 69v, 77v, 96v, 109r, 115v, 125v; initials in plain red or in two color combinations at the beginning of the rest of the books on folios 81r, 84v, 88r, 89r, 101r, 106v, 126v, 131r, 182v, 199r, 209v; 2- to 6-line initials in alternating plain red and plain dark red, some of which are decorated in opposite colors, at the beginning of each book section; 1-line initials in alternating red, dark red and black, at the beginning of each line; rubrics in red; running titles for each book in red in upper margins; occasional paragraph marks in red; line fillers in plain red; guide initials, some of which are in red, are mostly visible either on the inner margins along the spine-folds or on fore-edge margins next to the pricking marks.|Binding: Early modern. Bound in full leather dyed light brown over paper boards. Blind-tooling on front and back cover. All three edges of the bookblock are sprinkled red. Binding is worn, especially damaged around the corners and along the spine.|Origin: Probably written in southern France or Spain around 1200.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C195|In good condition despite missing leaves. Major imperfections on parchment, including holes and knife wounds as well as yellowing. The quality and thickness of the parchment varies throughout the manuscript. Several leaves are repurposed and palimpsest, with remnants of earlier texts partly visible on folios 64, 65, 66, 67. Evidence of sewn tabs along the fore-edge, corresponding to the beginning of books on folios 32, 55, 69, 78, 81, 84, 89, 109, 115, 125, 137, 182, 199, 210. Contemporary interlinear corrections and marginal additions, including the use of technical signs such as asteriscus, cryphia and require, probably by the scribe. Nota signs, some of which are decorated and in red, throughout, also probably by the scribe. Few modern marginal annotations by at least two hands, including a sign that resembles a trefoil.|The copy of the Aurora by Peter Riga in this manuscript is the so-called third edition of the work except that it does not contain the book titled "Recapitulationes" according to the modern edition (Aurora. Petri Rigae Biblia versificata: A Verse Commentary on the Bible. Ed. Paul. E. Beichner. Publications in Mediaeval Studies 19. 2 vols. Notre Dame, IN: University of Notre Dame Press, 1965). The rest of the books are in the same order as the edition in MS C195.|The first two leaves of the original second gathering (now the third quire) were dismembered and are missing; its last two leaves were misbound (now the second quire). The correct order of the folios for the first book of the Aurora (the "Liber Genesis") are as follows: folios 7r-10v ("[incipit] Si firmo sensu sc[ri]pta notare velis ... [explicit] Scia q[ui]ppe noce[n]t anim[a]e p[ro]dest labor illi."), folios 5r-6v ("[incipit] H[ec] mala m[u]lta move[n]t h[ic] bona m[u]lta parit ... [explicit] I[n] foribus mentis crime[n] ade[n]e scias."), folios 11r-31v ("[incipit] His forib[us] deb[et] signari p[ra]va voluntas ... [explicit] Supplica[n]t huic f[rate]r ille remittit eis. [rubric] Explicit lib[er] genesis."). Folio 183r is blank; the text breaks off at the end of folio 182v ("Actus Apostolorum," line 30) and resumes on folio 183v with no missing text, either a sign of miscalculation during the copying of the manuscript or due to the fragile nature of that particular leaf.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Charterhouse of Notre-Dame de Montrieux (Chartreuse de Montrieux) in Méounes-les-Montrieux, France according to a note in a modern hand on paper with a printed letterhead "Ministère de la Guerre" pasted over the front pastedown: "Ce manuscrit qui faisait partie de la bibliothéque de l'ancienne Chartreuse de Montrieux (Monsrivus) dans le d[é]p[artemen]t du Var a été offert à M. Hambert conseiller à la Cour de Cassation par M. Ruel, son ancien camarade de collége. Paris 5 Fevrier 1841." The identities of M. Ruel and M. Hambert remain unknown. Bookseller marks in pencil on front and back pastedowns.

note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: i (parchment, pastedown) + 34 (parchment) + i (parchment, pastedown): 1-3⁸ + 4¹⁰.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (5, 10, 15, 16, 19, 20, 30, 34).|Layout: Written in 21 long lines, below top line. Ruled in ink, with single full-length vertical bounding lines in either ink or lead.|Script: Written by a single hand (?) in Gothic rotunda.|Decoration: A 7-line foliate initial P in pink, blue, red, black and green on gold background on folio 1r; a 6-line initial F in blue with dark red penwork on folio 2v; a 6-line initial M in red with gray penwork on folio 19r; a 4-line initial C in blue with dark red penwork on folio 20r; most rubrics in red; sentence initials touched in red throughout.|Binding: Fifteenth-century, possibly original. Bound in full dark brown leather over wooden boards, with three alum-tawed slit straps. Blind-tooling with concentric interlaced strapwork design on front and back cover. Three raised bands. Leather straps are broken off and are missing together with clasps. Two sets of four rivets with a star-shaped design on the fore-edge of the front cover and two lipped catchplates nailed to the board on the fore-edge of the back cover are present. Minor damage to the binding, especially on the corners and along the spine, with part of tail of spine broken off and missing.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the third quarter of the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y96|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C49|In relatively good condition despite heavy water damage that caused discoloration of parchment on upper part of the manuscript towards fore-edge, especially in last quire. Lower half of folio 4 excised, with no loss of text. A series of contemporary corrections and additions, including use of technical signs such as trigons and trifolia. Manicules on folios 3r, 7v, 8r, 8v, 9v, 10r, 10v, 11r, 11v, 12v, 13r, 17r, 21v, 23r, 23v, 24r, 25r, 26r, 27r, 27v, 28r, 28v, 31v, 32r, 32v, 33r, 34r.|History of the manuscript is unknown. Partly legible ownership inscription on lower margin on folio 1r, unidentified: "Iste liber est d[omi]ni Philippi [?]". Possible bookseller marks in pencil: inscribed "8620 / JC" on upper left corner of front pastedown and "817" on upper margin of folio 1r.

physical_description: Extent: 126 leaves : paper, illuminations ; 212 x 145 (155 x 95) mm bound to 213 x 145 mm
note: Title from closing rubric on folio 123v.|Manuscript codex|Collation: 126 (paper): 1-10¹² + 11⁶.|Foliation: Contemporary foliation in ink, probably by the scribe, in upper right corner (i-cxxvi). Foliation supplied in Hindu-Arabic numerals by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords to the right of center inside rhombus-like frames in red on folios 12v, 24v, 36v, 48v, 60v, 72v, 84v, 96v, 108v, 120v.|Watermarks: Three watermarks: two conjoined bull's heads in profile facing away from each other (very similar to WZIS DE3315-GMVIb.E.87._50); a horn (similar to Briquet BR 7676); a dragon (similar to WZIS DE4620-PO-124019).|Layout: Written in 20-30 long lines, usually above top line, but not consistently. Folios 24v, 62r (partly), 62v, 125r, 125v are in two columns, all of which contain tables of contents. Frame ruled in lead, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on the outer margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic cursive.|Decoration: 8-line boxed initials S, O, D in red, dark brown/black and purple with pen-flourished foliate borders in purple, which may have been added later and which are seemingly left incomplete, on folios 1v, 24v, 63r respectively; 2- to 3-line initials in plain red throughout; sentence initials highlighted in red; most rubrics in red; tables of contents entirely in red on folios 1r, 24v, 62r, 62v; the entirety of table of contents underlined in red on folios 125r and 125v; guide letters visible on most leaves.|Binding: Romanesque, possibly original. Bound in full reversed leather over wooden boards, with three slit straps and endbands laced through channels and fixed with nails on the front of the board. The cover, the straps and the endbands seem to have been dyed red, which is now mostly faded. Tail endband and the sewing support closer to the tail are broken. Blind-tooling on front and back cover, featuring a series of double-lined rhombuses. Most of the leather on the front board is destroyed, seemingly due to bookworm damage, and the spine is partly exposed. A rectangular paper label, covering most of the middle of the spine, with a handwritten inscription in ink "No. XXXX / CXXXVI" and with remnants of a red wax seal. A spiked round paper label adhered to the lower part of the larger rectangular label, with a handwritten inscription in ink: "4o / 74529 / S.III.0."|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y111.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C54.|In good condition except for yellowing and foxing on paper throughout, especially on the outer edges of the leaves. Bookworm damage throughout, especially worse on the first and last leaves, with some loss of text. Remnants of a parchment fragment on the head edge turn-in of the back cover, which possibly indicates that the manuscript originally had repurposed parchment pastedowns. Red stains on all three outer edges of the bookblock. Drypoint sketches of two faces in profile on outer margin on folio 8v. Sketch of an initial A on the inside of the back board. Few interlinear and marginal corrections by the scribe. Nota bene signs throughout, most of which seem to be by the scribe. Manicules, most of which seem to be by the scribe and most of which are decorated and highlighted in red, on folios 5r, 5v, 9r, 10v, 22v, 29r, 38v, 41r, 41v, 42r, 43r, 44v, 47v, 48r, 52v, 53v, 64v, 65r, 68v, 77r, 88r, 88v, 91r, 96v, 104v, 107r, 108v, 111r.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Bookseller annotations on the inside of the front board: inscribed in pencil in the upper part: "No. 74529"; a piece of paper adhered to the lower half with a note in blue ink in a modern hand about the contents of the manuscript: "S. Isidorus Hispal[ensis] / Sententiarum libri III / De summo bono / User du XV s[iècle]." Additional annotations by a later hand in pencil on the lower part of the same piece of paper, including an inventory number "23981/422."

physical_description: Extent: 206 leaves : paper and parchment ; 239 x 182 (152 x 102) mm bound to 244 x 182 mm +
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: i (parchment, pastedown) + iv (paper) + 206 (paper and parchment) + iv (paper) + i (parchment, pastedown): 1-14¹⁰ + 15¹² + 16⁸ + 17-20¹⁰ + 21¹⁰ (wants 7-10). All leaves in the first two quires are parchment. In the rest of the quires only the outermost and innermost leaves are parchment except for quire sixteen and twenty in which only the outermost leaves are parchment. The final leaf of quire twenty-one, which is missing, was also presumably parchment.|Foliation: Two sets of foliation in upper right corner: contemporary (?) foliation in ink (17-58 on folios 151-193; 11-16 on folios 194-199); modern foliation in pencil (1-99, 93[bis], 94[bis], 95[bis], 96[bis], 97[bis], 98[bis], 99[bis], 100-199. The description follows the modern foliation in pencil.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords, some flourished, at center on folios 10v, 20v, 30v, 40v, 50v, 60v, 70v, 80v, 90v, 93[bis]v, 103v, 113v, 123v, 133v, 145v, 153v, 163v, 173v, 193v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks on the front flyleaves: letter C with an upside down trifoliate flower (unidentified); three crescents (unidentified); two watermarks in the textblock: a triple mound (similar to Briquet BR 11662); an encircled triple mound (unidentified); single watermark on the back flyleaves: letter C with an upside down trifoliate flower (same as the front flyleaves, unidentified).|Layout: Written in 28 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length vertical bounding lines and a full-length horizontal bounding line in the upper margin.|Script: Written by multiple hands in Humanistic bookhand and Humanistic cursive, with clear change of hands on folios 134r and 184r. Rubrics added by at least three other hands.|Decoration: 11-line initial M in red with blue penwork at the beginning of Book I on folio 1r; 2- to-8-line initials in plain blue at the beginning of the rest of the books on folios 40v, 65r, 94v, 118v, 149r, 178v; 2- to 3-line initials at the beginning of chapters in alternating plain red and plain blue throughout; spaces left for initials on folios 46v, 48v, 182v; rubrics in light brown (folios 1r-59v; 65r-133v), red (folios 60r-65r; 154r-163v) and pink (folios 134r-153v; 164r-199r); guide letters visible to the left of the initials for the most part.|Binding: Modern. Bound in full leather over paper boards. Four raised bands. Sewn endbands in cream and yellow. Title area at the head of spine between the first and second raised bands is dyed black and gold-tooled. All three edges of the bookblock are sprinkled red.|Accompanying materials: Two detached paper slips, both written by the same late hand, placed between folios 178-179 and 181-182 respectively. The first (145 x 50 mm) notes that the prologue to Book VII does not exist in the print edition: "Quid dicam est in precedntibus [sic] libris ec... Questo prologo manca nello stampato." The second (83 x 58 mm) notes that there is no missing text where there is a lacuna on folios 181v-182v: "Qui non manca niente."|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y118|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C61|In good condition except for missing leaves and staining and soiling on the recto of first leaf and the verso of last leaf. Minor imperfections on parchment leaves; minor soiling on a few leaves with no loss of text. Témoins (folded corner of the leaf which was uncut during trimming) on the upper right corner of folio 151 and upper left corner of folio 192. Upper right corner of folio 43 is torn and the last folio is damaged along the fore-edge. Recto of the first front flyleaf and the verso of the last back flyleaf are stained from turn-ins. Some loss of text on the recto of the first leaf, with some of the damaged parts of the text supplied as overwriting by a later hand. Corrections, additions, deletions and other marginal annotations by multiple contemporary hands, including the use of technical signs such as oculus and brackets. Minor loss of marginal annotations on a number of leaves due to trimming on the fore-edge. Book numbers (I-VII) added in upper margins at center on the recto side of leaves, presumably by one of the annotators who might have also added part of the rubrics. Manicules on folios 25v, 130v, 131r, 137v, 138r, 180v, 196r.|The passages in Greek in the Divinae Institutiones in this manuscript are supplied in Latin. The text breaks off at the end of line 9 on folio 181v (end of Book VII.2) and resumes on line 10 on folio 182v (beginning of Book VII.3), with no missing text, clearly a sign of miscalculation during the copying of the manuscript. At the end of the manuscript (on folio 199v), the text breaks off five lines into Book VII.18 and the rest of the chapters are missing.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Bookseller annotations in pencil on the recto of the first front flyleaf, mostly erased with only "155" remaining in lower left corner (possibly by Jacques Rosenthal). Unidentified stamp in blue ink reading "Amministr. da Porto" on the lower half of the verso of the last back flyleaf.

former_owner_as_recorded: Ess, Leander van, 1772-1847|Phillipps, Thomas, Sir, 1792-1872|Fenwick, Katherine Somerset Wyttenbach, 1823-1913|Fenwick, Thomas FitzRoy Phillipps, 1856-1938|Kölner Kartause
former_owner_label: Johann Heinrich van Ess|Thomas Phillipps|Katherine Somerset Wyttenbach Fenwick|Thomas FitzRoy Phillipps Fenwick|Cologne Charterhouse
physical_description: Extent: 96 leaves : paper and parchment ; 200 x 130 (164 x 105) mm bound to 218 x 142 mm
note: Title from closing rubric on folio 72v.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (parchment, i is pastedown) + 96 (paper and parchment) + ii (parchment): 1¹⁸ + 2²⁰ + 3¹⁴ + 4-5¹⁶ + 6¹². Only the innermost leaves of the first quire are parchment (folios 9 and 10).|Foliation: Two sets of foliation: contemporary foliation in ink, possibly by the scribe, at center in upper margin (i-lxxii); modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner on the remaining leaves (73-96). Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed A-F in pencil in lower right corner on the recto of first folio of each gathering beginning with the first quire by Alexandra Mason, March 1963.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right on folios 18v, 38v, 52v, 68v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks: a detached crossbow with stirrup (similar to Gravell CRSBW.053.1); a lily (fleur-de-lis) with a rectangular stem (unidentified).|Layout: Written in 2 columns of 44-47 lines (folios 1r-10r) and in 33-39 long lines (folios 10v-95r), above top line (folios 1r-94r), below top line (folios 94v-95r). Frame ruled in drypoint (folios 1-10), in lead (folios 11-94) and in ink (folios 94v-95r), all with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic cursive.|Decoration: 2- to 6-line initials in plain red (folios 3r-62v); spaces left for 2- to 4-line initials (folios 73r-81v); sentence initials highlighted in red; words and phrases underlined in red; paragraph marks in red; chapter numbers in red; rubrics in red. Guide letters visible to the left of initials on most folios.|Binding: Contemporary, possibly original. Bound in dark brown quarter leather and wooden boards, with four alum-tawed slit straps with single herringbone sewing laced through channels. Evidence of a closure structure, most likely a single long pin strap hinging from the back cover, with all components lost. Front board worn. Some of the leather on the spine is destroyed, leaving the spine and especially the sewing supports exposed. Six paper labels adhered to spine from head to tail in the following order: a rectangular label with a typeset number "59" corrected to "259" by adding 2 in ink; a rectangular label with typeset letters "OO"; remnants of two rectangular labels; a rectangular label with a typeset number "644" corrected to "642" by crossing out 4 and replacing it with 2 in pencil; a round label with a handwritten number "497" in ink.|Origin: Probably written in the Charterhouse of St Barbara in Cologne, Germany in the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y122|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 642|Related shelfmark: Cologne, Historisches Archiv der Stadt Köln, Best. 233 Kartäuser, Repertorien und Handschriften, Nr. 14|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C64|In good condition except for minor bookworm damage at the tail of the first two quires and at the head of the fifth quire near the spine-folds which caused paper to tear, especially worse in the first quire. Approximately 15 mm of parchment is cut out of the head of the front flyleaf and approximately 20 mm of paper is cut out of the tail of the first folio. The latter seems to have contained an inscription, possibly that of an ownership. Signs of early repairs on paper. The spine-fold of the first gathering is supported by an approximately 18 mm parchment strip adhered to the outermost leaves. In the remaining gatherings, the center-folds are supported by approximately 15 mm parchment strips that are adhered to the innermost leaves of each quire. Most of the parchment strips, seemingly coming from different manuscripts, are repurposed and contain texts (unidentified). Ten parchment tabs adhered to the outer edges of leaves, corresponding to folios 1, 10, 19, 25 (now torn together with the paper to which it was adhered and lost), 30, 40, 45, 56, 73, 82. A number of contemporary marginal annotations, mostly by the scribe.|The front pastedown and the flyleaf are made up of a single repurposed parchment leaf folded in half. The recto side (now the pastedown and the recto of the flyleaf) contains De viris illustribus urbis Romae / Pseudo-Sextus Aurelius Victor [incomplete; chapters 75-77]: "[acephalous] [incipit] accepit bello Tymbrico et Teutonico legat[us] bona[m] op[er]am manavit [sic] .... [explicit] Qui no[n] [con]ti[nens] lac[ri]mas illud plurimis [et] p[re]ciosissim[is] [o]dorib[us] cremandu[m] curavit." The outer margin of the leaf (now the tail edge of the pastedown and the flyleaf) is trimmed, with some loss of text. Probably dated to the fifteenth century and written in Gothic cursive, in two columns of 46 lines, below topline; frame ruled in lead, with full-length double vertical and horizontal bounding lines. The verso of the front flyleaf (originally blank) contains the table of contents of the manuscript, amended by later hands.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Charterhouse of St. Barbara in Cologne, Germany (Kölner Kartause). Sixteenth-century shelfmark of the library inscribed in ink in upper right corner on folio 1r: "g.22." Seventeenth-century label of the library adhered to head of spine: "OO." Listed as "OO 134" in the seventeenth-century shelflist of the library, Cologne, Historisches Archiv der Stadt Köln, Best. 233 Kartäuser, Repertorien und Handschriften, Nr. 14. After the dissolution of the Charterhouse of St. Barbara in Cologne in 1794, some of the manuscripts in its library were sold. During these sales, some hundred and thirty-six manuscripts were acquired by Johann Matthias Heberle (Antiquargeschäft mit Auktionsanstalt Cologne) and then sold in 1821 to Leander van Ess (Johann Heinrich van Ess). MS C64 was one of these manuscripts. In 1824, Leander Van Ess sold the manuscript along with others that formerly belonged to the Charterhouse of St. Barbara to Sir Thomas Phillipps. It is inscribed "Phillipps MS 642" in ink at center on verso of front flyleaf and there is a rectangular Phillipps label with a typeset number "644" corrected to "642" adhered to tail of spine. Listed as no. 642 under "Catalogus Bibliothecae Manuscriptorum Leandri van Ess, S. T. D." in The Phillipps Manuscripts. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. In 1910, the manuscript was sold by Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick to J. & J. Leighton in a Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge auction of Phillipps manuscripts. The round label with a handwritten number "497" in ink adhered to tail of spine probably belongs to this auction. In 1911, the manuscript was purchased from J. & J. Leighton by Jacques Rosenthal. Bookseller marks in pencil on front pastedown and recto of second back flyleaf.

note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (paper, i is pastedown) + 60 (paper) + xvi (paper, xvi is pastedown): 1-7⁸ + 8⁴.|Foliation: Two sets of modern foliation in pencil: in upper right corner (1-75; including the flyleaves at the end) and at center (1, 28, 30, 40, 41). The description follows the modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner.|Catchwords: Vertical catchwords in lower right corner on folios 8v, 16v, 24v, 32v; horizontal catchwords at center on folios 48v, 56v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks on the front flyleaves: a detached crossbow with stirrup, with a single-lined arch and a double-lined shaft (similar to Piccard PPO 9-11-2135); a monogram with the letters RWB? (unidentified); two watermarks in the text block: a goat's head with smooth curled horns (similar to Piccard PPO 15.3-3-271); a detached flower with five petals (found only on one sheet, similar to Briquet BR 6349); two watermarks on the back flyleaves: a detached crossbow with stirrup, with a single-lined arch and a double-lined shaft ending with an arrow head (different than the one on the front flyleaves; unidentified); letters CC with an upside down trifoliate flower underneath (unidentified).|Layout: Written in 25 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic rotunda.|Decoration: Two drawings of a tree in plain red illustrating different concepts related to sin on folios 29v and 35r; 2- to 6-line initials in plain red throughout; paragraph marks in red (folios 1r-39v); initials highlighted in red (folios 1r-39v); most of the opening rubrics and section headings in red.|Binding: Early modern. Parchment case binding over thin paper boards with laced-in alum-tawed endbands. Four repurposed paper strips adhered to the spine to reinforce the attachment of the covers are partly visible underneath the pastedowns on both sides. A spiked round paper label adhered to the tail of the spine, with a modern handwritten inscription now effaced.|Origin: Probably written in Italy and completed on April 5, 1449: "Scriptum mccccxlviiiio die v ap[ri]lis." -- colophon, folio 58v.|Former shelfmark: MS Y124|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C65|In good condition except for some ink transfer on a few leaves. Annotations in a contemporary hand on folios 59r and 60v.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Bookseller or ownership marks on spine: inscribed "18" in brown ink and "99" in pencil on head of spine. Paper label adhered to tail of spine. Possible bookseller annotations in pencil on front pastedown, now erased. Inscribed "99" in pencil on upper left corner of first front flyleaf. Both cases of the inscription "99" on spine and first front flyleaf probably belongs to Jacques Rosenthal, who listed this manuscript in his 1925 catalog under number 99.

note: Title from opening rubric on folio 1r.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (modern paper, i is pastedown) + ii (modern paper) + 90 (paper) + ii (modern paper, ii is pastedown): 1-9¹⁰|Foliation: Two sets of foliation: contemporary foliation in ink, possibly by the scribe, in upper right corner (1-81); modern foliation in pencil at center in upper margin (81, 85, 90). Missing foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed A-I in pencil in lower right corner on the recto of first folio of each gathering by Alexandra Mason, May 1963.|Watermarks: Two watermarks in the textblock: a bull's head surmounted by a cross around which a serpent is twined (found only on one sheet, similar to WZMA AT8500-4546_99); an encircled anchor surmounted by a star (similar to Piccard PPO 6-5-195); single watermark on the accompanying material: a pair of lilies (fleurs-de-lis) (unidentified).|Layout: Written in 27 long lines, below top line. Single pricking marks visible on the tail-edge margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by Suor [Sister] Lena from the women's monastery of San Francesco della Croce in Venice, Italy in Italian Gothica Hybrida Libraria/Currens.|Decoration: 2-line initials in plain red, excised and pasted from another manuscript (folios 1r-81v); sentence initials highlighted in red; most rubrics in red.|Binding: Modern; after 1852. Bound in brown leather over paper boards. Blind-tooling on front and back cover. Four raised bands. A spiked round paper label adhered to tail of spine, with a handwritten inscription in ink: "S.III.5 / Hugo de Palm[a] [underlined] / Ms. 1500 / 4o.74414."|Accompanying materials: A note from Bartolomeo Sorio to Domenico Turazza, written sideways on the upper half of one side of a single sheet of paper. The sheet is folded into two and tipped in between the front flyleaves and the textblock, now forming a bifolium.|Origin: Written by a nun of the order of St Clare, Suor [Sister] Lena, from the women's monastery of San Francesco della Croce in Venice, Italy and completed on December 3, 1500: "Scrita nel monast[er]io de le done de Sa[n] Fra[n]çesco della crose de Vei[n]esia de lordene de S[an]c[t]a Chiara de hoserva[n]çia. Nelliani del n[ost]ro signor mis[er] Ih[es]u Chr[ist]o 1500 finito a di 3 deçe[m]brio. S[uor] Le? Bol?. E tu lezitore prega Dio p[er] el scritore. Amen. De s[uor] Lena [...]. Sc[ri]to de sua mano." -- colophon, folio 81v.|Former shelfmark: MS Y128|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C66|In good condition except for minor water damage on the tail edge, near spine-folds and outer corners. Front and back pastedowns, flyleaves and the first few leaves are stained from the turn-ins. Staining in the left margin on folio 81v. Minor damage on the binding along the spine and the outer edges. Very few marginal corrections by the scribe.|MS C66 was one of the two primary witnesses to the text used by Bartolomeo Sorio in the 1852 edition, La Teologia mistica attribuita a San Bonaventura (siglum MS Veneto).|The manuscript was owned by its scribe, Suor [Sister] Lena, a nun of the order of St Clare from the women's monastery of San Francesco della Croce in Venice, Italy in 1500, according to the colophon on folio 81v. It was later part of the collection of Domenico Turazza of the University of Padua, Italy, during which time the 1852 edition of the De theologia mystica was prepared. It was loaned by Domenico Turazza to Bartolomeo Sorio, the editor of the work: correspondence from Bartolomeo Sorio to Domenico Turazza now accompanies the manuscript. Bookseller marks on front pastedown by different hands: inscribed in pencil "Hugo Carthusiensis / Venice 1500" in upper left and "MS. 114" in lower right corner; in blue crayon "36" in lower half.

physical_description: Extent: 199 leaves : paper and parchment ; 215 x 140 (151-158 x 95-105) mm bound to 223 x 146 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (modern paper, i is pastedown) + 199 (paper and parchment) + iv (modern paper, iv is pastedown): 1-2¹² + 3¹⁰ + 4-6¹² + 7¹² (wants 10, 11, 12) + 8-17¹². The outermost and innermost leaves of each gathering are parchment whereas the rest of the leaves are paper, except for quire seven, which is missing its last three leaves (after folio 79) one of which was also presumably parchment.|Foliation: Three sets of foliation in upper right corner: modern foliation in blue ink (1-5), contemporary foliation in brown ink (6-,79, 83-197), modern foliation in pencil (80-83, 90, 100-101, 125, 130, 140-151, 160, 180, 190-199). The description follows the contemporary foliation in brown ink until folio 79 and the modern foliation in pencil afterwards.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords at center or to the right of center on folios 24v, 34v, 46v, 58v, 70v, 91v, 103v, 115v, 127v, 139v, 151v, 163v, 175v, 187v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks in the textblock: a cart/chariot on two wheels (unidentified); a capital letter R (very similar to Briquet BR 8938).|Layout: Written in 2 columns of 33-42 lines, above top line. Ruled in lead.|Script: Probably written by a single hand in Humanistic cursive.|Decoration: 2-line initials in plain red, rubrics in red; chapter numbers in red; sentence initials highlighted in red throughout. Guide letters visible for the most part.|Binding: Modern. Parchment binding over paper boards with semi yapp edges on the fore-edge.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y290|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C143|In good condition despite minor damage around corners of leaves, especially in first and last quire. Wear and tear on final leaf, with ink on verso of leaf faded and text illegible at places. Partial transcriptions and annotations in blue ink by a modern hand on folios 1r, 2r, 22r, 65v, 75v, 76r and 82v. Very few other annotations and corrections, some of which are by the same 1682 hand. Manicule on folio 18v.|Item 4 was identified by Alfredo Troiano, Naples, Italy, 2020.|The manuscript seems to have been in the possession of a Nicandro of San Nicandro, perhaps a Franciscan friar, in 1682 according to two annotations: "Questo libro è di bellis[sim]i esempii ripieno mà non sintende troppo e parla zaffio. Fr[ate?] Nicandro d[a] S[an] Nicand[ro]. 2 Gen[naio] 1682. Finis." on 73v and "Fr[ate?] Nicandro d[a] S[an] N[ican]d[ro] li 18[?] Gen[naio] 1682." on 80vb. The manuscript was later in the possession of a Geremia Alfonso Piemonte around 1869-1872, possibly canon and priest of the Lucera Cathedral in Apulia, Italy according to an annotation on 73v: "Nel 1682 questo libro non era totalmente capito come si vede dalle saprascritte [sic] parole. Dunque deve essere molto più antico, epperò sembrami del 1500[?]. Io lo capisco. Geremia Alfonso Sac[erdote] Piemonte. Lucera li 20 Giugno 1872 [72 written over 69]." From the collection of Giuseppe Martini according to the information in the List 189 of H. P. Kraus. Bookseller marks: collation of the manuscript on the lower right corner of the back pastedown dated to January 1958: "[Pro] HPK [H. P. Kraus] JSK [J. S. Kebabian] I/58" as well as a annotations by H. P. Kraus ("WW1/1A/17" crossed out and replaced with "Vt 2/2/3") and price on the upper part of front pastedown.

subject_label: Phalaris, Tyrant of Agrigentum, active 6th century B.C.|Manuscripts, Medieval|Manuscripts, Medieval;Kansas--Lawrence|Manuscripts, Latin|Epistolaries;Early works|Correspondence;Early works
physical_description: Extent: 40 leaves : parchment ; 202 x 144 (142 x 94) mm bound to 210 x 148 mm
note: Title from title page (added later): "Phalaridis Tyranni Agrigentini Epistolae ex Greco in Latinum versae per Franciscum Dulcem Anno Domini 1460 Genuae."|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (paper, i is pastedown) + 40 (parchment) + ii (paper, ii is pastedown): 1 leaf (added later) + 2⁸ (wants 1, 2) + 3⁸ + 4¹⁰ + 5⁸ + 6⁸ (wants 7, 8, possibly blank) + 1 leaf (misbound).|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords at center on folios 7v, 15v, 25v, 33v.|Watermarks: Two different watermarks on front and back flyleaves, both dated to 1819 and found in manuscripts and books from Genoa, Italy. 1. Watermark with a double contoured shield, on which there is a crowned lion in right profile, supported by two lions. Underneath the shield it reads Bento Picardo in capital letters, and underneath a number 4 (Bernstein Portal, no. Tecnicelpa 628). 2. Watermark with a polygonal star with six points. Underneath the star it reads Gervino in capital letters (Bernstein Portal, no. Tecnicelpa 674).|Layout: Written in 26 long lines, below top line. Ruled in drypoint.|Script: Written by Antonius de Bozollo in Humanistic bookhand [see origin].|Decoration: 2- to 3-line initials in gold with black penwork, blue with red penwork, gold with light blue penwork throughout; rubrics in red; headings in red.|Binding: Modern, early nineteenth century. Bound in full leather dyed in green, gold-tooled. Four raised bands. Gold-tooling on spine; title areas are of leather dyed in light brown and onlaid, perhaps taken from an earlier binding as the endings of the words are cut off. All three edges of the bookblock is sprinkled red. Minor damage around the corners and scratches on both covers.|Origin: Written by Antonius de Bozollo probably in Genoa, Italy and completed on June 1, 1463: "Perfecte sunt per me Antonium de Boçollo notarium et in p[raese]ntiarum subcancellarium. Anno dominice nativitatis MoccccoLxotercio die primo Iunii. Duce r[evenrendissi]mo in Ch[rist]o p[at]re et illustri domino. P[aolus] dei gratia archiep[iscop]o Ianuen[si]" -- colophon, folio 39r.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C277|Related shelfmark: San Francisco, State of California, Sutro Collection,  Sutro Collection MS 07|Related shelfmark: Cambridge, Harvard University, Houghton Library,  MS Typ 17|San Francisco, State of California, Sutro Collection, MS 07 also contains the Epistles of Phalaris copied by Antonius de Bozollo. Cambridge, Harvard University, Houghton Library, MS Typ 17 bears an ownership inscription of Antonius de Bozollo.|In good condition except for minor water damage on the upper part of fore-edge and a few ink smears. Few corrections, possibly by the scribe themself. The first two leaves of the original first gathering were dismembered, the first of which is missing and the second leaf is misbound, now at the end of the codex (folio 40). A title page was added to the manuscript to replace the initial leaf that had gone missing and the first letter of the first word of the text ("arbitror") on what was originally the third leaf (now folio 2r) was turned into a penwork initial. Note in Italian by a modern hand on the contents of the manuscript pasted on front pastedown.|Early history of the manuscript is uncertain. It seems that the manuscript stayed in or around Genoa, Italy at least until the nineteenth century after it was copied by Antonius de Bozollo [see origin and watermarks]. Note in Italian by an unidentified modern hand pasted on front pastedown. Possible bookseller mark in pencil on lower left corner of back pastedown: "pippa." Bookseller mark of Bernard M. Rosenthal in pencil on lower left corner of recto of first flyleaf: an encircled "MS 176."

note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: 84 (paper): 1-7¹²|Foliation: Contemporary foliation in ink in upper margin: at center (i-xxv), to the right (xxvi-xxxiii), in the corner (xxxiiii-lxxxiiii). Foliation supplied in Hindu-Arabic numerals by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords at center on folios 12v, 24v, 36v, 48v, 60v, 72v.|Watermarks: Watermarks present (unidentified).|Layout: Written in 25-27 long lines, above top line. Frame ruled in lead with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks are visible on the head and tail edges.|Script: Written by a single hand in pre-Humanistic cursive.|Decoration: 2-line initials in plain red at the beginning of each sermon on folios 1r, 2v, 3r, 23v, 28r, 54r, 77r, 78r, 79r, with spaces left for initials (with no guide letters visible) in the remainder of the manuscript; sentence initials highlighted in red on folios 1r-5r, 23v-24r, 27v-28r, 53v-54r, 76v-77r, 78r-79r; rubrics in red on folios 23v, 54r, 77r, 78r-78v; rubrics underlined in red on folios 1r-5r, 77r, 79r; occasional paragraph marks in red.|Binding: Sewn on three alum-tawed double thongs and single supports at head and tail; cover missing. The sewing supports and the tailband are broken off and the rest of them are missing, together with the headband.|Origin: Probably written in the second half of the fourteenth century in Italy.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C278|The 55 sermons in this manuscript are found in the following order according to the numbering of the sermons by Schneyer (Johannes Baptist Schneyer. "Nicolaus (Nicolutius) de Asculo (Esculo) OP." In Repertorium der lateinischen Sermones des Mittelalters für die Zeit von 1150-1350. Beiträge zur Geschichte der Philosophie und Theologie des Mittelalters 43. 11 vols. (Münster: Aschendorffsche Verlagsbuchhandlung, 1969). 4: 205-28): 115-124, 126, 125, 127-135, unlisted sermon, 136-168. The unlisted sermon found on folios 35r-36v is entitled "[I]nfer digitu[m] tuu[m] huc [et] vide Joh[an]nis 20." The collection is attributed to Simon de Cremona by a later (fifteenth-century?) hand on folio 84v.|MS C278 contains loose continuous sewing guards in each gathering: the center-folds are supported by approximately 20 mm parchment strips and the spine-folds by approximately 25 to 40 mm parchment strips. These parchment sewing guards, seemingly coming from different but contemporary manuscripts, are all repurposed and contain texts (unidentified).|In good condition despite missing cover. Minor water damage and staining on the fore-edge. Minor bookworm damage on the head- and tail-edges with no loss of text. Deckle edges occasionally visible on the tail-edge. Few contemporary marginal annotations.|History of the manuscript is unknown.

note: Title from the opening rubric of the preface on folio 1r: "Prefacio in opusculum de formandis epistolis."|Manuscript gathering|Collation: 10 (paper): 1¹⁰.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in lower right corner (1-10).|Watermarks: Single watermark in the textblock: a crown with pearls surmounted by a cross (very similar to WZIS DE4860-Arist_17_5_F3).|Layout: Written in one to three columns of 14-41 lines (ruled 14 long lines), with several interlinear and marginal additions, usually below topline. Ruled in drypoint, with double horizontal and full-length double vertical bounding lines.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica textualis and Gothic cursive.|Decoration: Initials highlighted and phrases underlined in red on folios 1v-2r and 3v-4r; space left for initial B on folio 3r.|Binding: Modern. Bound in a thin sheet of blue paper. Edges of the cover discolored and brittle.|Origin: Probably written in Germany in the first quarter of the sixteenth century.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C283|In good condition despite missing leaves. Fore-edge trimmed, with some loss of text. Minor water damage on the fore-edge and some staining on the head in the second half of the manuscript.|There are eighteen chapters listed in the table of contents on folio 3r. The chapters are not numbered throughout the text; however, based on the titles of chapters, it seems like Chapter 8 was omitted and the text breaks off in the middle of the first sentence of Chapter 11. The rest of the text is missing.|The dimensions provided for the written area are for the ruled area; the text often spreads out on to the entire page.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Inscription in ink in the lower margin of the front cover: "1700." Note in pencil on the upper half of the inside of the front cover, probably by John Siedzik, an associate of Joseph Rubinstein and a former librarian at the University of Kansas: "# 748 / USXCS / 10 ff. / Opusculum de formandis epistolis / Italy (northern) or Germany? / ca. late 15th or 16th century / Cat. J. S. [John Siedzik?]."
