physical_description: Extent: 34 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 211 x 153 (127 x 77) mm bound to 215 x 160 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (parchment, reused) + 34 (parchment) + ii (parchment, reused): 1-2¹⁰ + 3¹² + 4² (1 and 2 are singletons).|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Decorated horizontal catchwords to the right of center on folios 10v, 20v, 32v.|Layout: Written in 31 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, with double vertical bounding lines.|Script: Written by a Robertus in Gothic rotunda.|Decoration: Drawings of fish and birds in lower margins on folios 9r, 10v, 11r, 20v; 6- line initial C in blue and red on folio 1r; 2- and 3-line initials throughout in two different kinds of plain red, some of which are embellished with pen decorations in blue or brown; paragraph marks in blue and red or in plain red; running title "p[er] germinias" in red in capital letters in upper margin on folios 19v-21r; spaces left for 2-, 3- and 5-line initials on folios 5r, 5v, 6r, 6v, 7r, 8r, 11v, 16v, 17r, 18r, 18v, 19r, 19v, 20r, 22v, 25r, 27r, 27v, 28v, 29r, 29v, 30v, 31v, 32r, 32v, 33r; guide letters, usually placed on the upper left corner of the space left for the initial, visible on most folios.|Music: Front flyleaves contain neumatic notation on a one-line staff in red.|Binding: Contemporary, possibly original. Parchment case binding made up of a reused bifolium with split laced double sewing supports made out of alum-tawed leather. Some of the sewing supports are broken off and missing.|Origin: Written by a Robertus probably in Italy in the fourteenth century: "Robertus nomine scripsit" -- colophon, folio 34r.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C189|The cover, the front flyleaves and the back flyleaves of MS C189 are made up of repurposed parchment leaves from three different manuscripts: a bifolium is used for the cover and two folios folded in half are used as flyleaves at the front and back.|The repurposed parchment bifolium used for the cover likely comes from a homiliary, probably dated to the second half of the eleventh century. It contains Isidore of Seville's Sententiae, Book 10.11 "De angelis" and a sermon titled "De misericordia" attributed to John Chrysostom, also known by its opening words, "Tria sunt quae in misericordiae opera." The upper margin of the bifolium (now the fore-edge turn-in of the front cover) is trimmed with no loss of text, with all edges of the cover left large enough to allow for turn-ins. Written in late Caroline minuscule, in two columns of 38 lines, ruled in drypoint.|The repurposed parchment folio used for the front flyleaves likely comes from an antiphonary, probably dated to the first half of the twelfth century. It contains John 6:1-14 and the following chants: "Tunc acceptabis sacrificium justitiae si averteris faciem tuam" [Cantus ID: 005236]; "Aperiam in parabolis os meum loquar propositiones" [Cantus ID: g01030b]; "Adduxi vos per desertum quadraginta annos" [Cantus ID: 006030]; "Adduxit eos dominus in fortitudine magna cibavit" [Cantus ID: 006032]. The upper margin of the leaf (now the outer edge of the first front flyleaf) is trimmed, with at least two lines of text lost. Outer and inner margins of the leaf are also trimmed, with some text lost on the outer margin (now the tail-edge). 18-line interlace initial I? in red and brown (partly cut off); rubrics in red. Written in Praegothica, in two columns of 34? lines, ruled in drypoint.|The repurposed parchment folio used for the back flyleaves likely comes from a breviary, probably dated to the first half of the twelfth century. It contains readings associated with Maundy Thursday and Good Friday of the Christian Holy Week. The recto side (now the recto side of the first back flyleaf and the verso side of the second back flyleaf) contains: Hosea 6:5-6 ("[incipit] [do]lui [?] in p[ro]phetis occidi eos in verbis oris mei ... [explicit] scientiam D[e]i plus quam holocausta."); Habakkuk 3:2-3: ("[incipit] Domine audivi auditum tuum [et] timui... [explicit] op[er]uit c[a]elos maiestas eius [et] laude eius plena"); reading for Maundy Thursday: "[incipit] Deus a quo et Iudas reatus sui penam ... [explicit] resurrectionis su[a]e gr[ati]am largiatur qui tec[um]."; Exodus 12:1-8: "[rubric] [Et] libri exodi. [incipit] In dieb[us] illis dixit d[omi]n[u]s ad Moysen et Aaron; iste vobis principium mensium [...] [explicit] panes cu[m] lactucis agrestib[us].") The verso side (now the verso side of the first back flyleaf and the recto side of the second back flyleaf) contains: Exodus 12:9-11 ("[incipit] quid nec coctum aqua sed assum tantum igni caput ... [explicit] comedetis festinantes est enim phase id est transitus d[omi]ni"; Psalm 139:2-14 ("[incipit] eripe me d[omi]ne ab homine malo ... adversum me ne derelinquas; [cir]cuitus eo[rum] labor labio[rum] ipso[rum] coop[er]i[et] ... [explicit] habitabunt recti cum vultu tuo"); John 18:1-5 ("[rubric] Passio d[omi]ni n[ost]ri Ih[es]u Chr[ist]I s[ancti] Ioh[anne]m. [incipit] In ill[o] t[empo]r[e] egressus est d[omi]n[u]s Ih[esu]s cum discipulis suis trans torrentem ... [explicit] stabat aut[em] et Iudas qui tradebat"). The upper margin of the leaf (now the outer edge of the second back flyleaf) is trimmed, with one line of text lost. 15-line zoomorphic white wine-stem initial I in red, green, blue and brown, with an eagle holding a book, representing St John; 4-line initial I in red and green; rubrics in red. Written in late Caroline minuscule, in two columns of 31 lines, ruled in drypoint.|In fragile condition, with extensive water damage that caused yellowing and staining of the leaves throughout the manuscript. Ink is abraded, with text illegible at places. Tears and holes with loss of text on several folios. Only the third quire is in relatively better condition. Minor imperfections and signs of early repairs on parchment of the textblock. The repurposed parchment leaves used for the cover and the flyleaves are cockled, with minor bookworm damage. Corrections, overwriting and annotations, including the use of technical signs such as trigons by at least two contemporary hands, one of which is probably the scribe. Later (fifteenth century?) annotations, especially on folios 19r-33r, by at least two hands. Some of the annotations on upper margins are lost due to damage to the parchment.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. From the collection of Alpha Loretta Owens, who purchased the manuscript sometime before 1935, probably in one of her visits to Europe. Listed as no. 1 under "The Library of Miss Alpha Loretta Owens, Barboursville, West Virginia" in the Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada.

physical_description: Extent: 198 leaves : parchment ; 178 x 131 (130 x 88) mm bound to 193 x 142 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (parchment, reused, i is pastedown) + 198 (parchment) + ii (parchment, reused, ii is pastedown): 1¹⁶ + 2¹⁸ + 3¹⁶ + 1 leaf after 16 + 4-5⁸ + 6-13¹⁶ + 14⁴ (wants 4).|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1-85, 85a, 86-197).|Signatures: Quires signed A-I, K-O in pencil in lower right corner on the recto side of leaves by Alexandra Mason, March 1963.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner on folios 16v, 34v, 50v, 59v, 67v, 83v, 98v, 114v, 130v, 146v, 162v, 194v.|Layout: Written in 35 long lines, above top line (except for folio 1r). Ruled in lead, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on the outer margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica Textualis Currens.|Decoration: 2- to 20-line initials in plain red with penwork in red; rubrics in two shades of red by two different hands; sentence initials highlighted in red; paragraph marks in red. Guide letters visible to the left of initials throughout; most guide rubrics visible in outer margins throughout.|Music: Front pastedown and flyleaf as well as back pastedown and flyleaf contain square notation on four-line staff in red.|Binding: Modern. Reversed leather dyed dark brown with a purple hue over paper boards. Four false raised bands. Evidence of a paper label adhered to the tail of spine.|Origin: Probably written in France in the second half of the thirteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Y125|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS B18|Abbreviatio summae Guillelmi Altissiodorensis by Herbert of Auxerre is thought to be based on Summa aurea by Guillermus of Auxerre, which was in turn based on Sententiarum libri IV by Peter Lombard. There is no modern edition of the Abbreviatio summae Guillelmi Altissiodorensis. A comparison of the text contained in MS B18 with those of other known manuscripts leads to the conclusion that only the very end of the work, which was on the final leaf of the codex, is missing.|The endleaves of MS B18 are made up of repurposed parchment leaves, possibly two consecutive leaves from the same manuscript, likely a breviary, probably dated to the fifteenth century: a folio cut to size and folded in half is used for the front pastedown and flyleaf and another for the back flyleaf and pastedown. Both leaves contain chants, most of which are associated with the Christian Feast of the Holy Innocents: front pastedown and flyleaf: "Hi sunt qui cum mulieribus" [Cantus ID: 003044]; "Hi empti sunt ex hominibus" [Cantus ID: 006273b]; "In conspectu agni amicti stolis" [Cantus ID: 007012a]; "Effuderunt sanguinem" [Cantus ID: 006624]; "Et cantabant quasi canticum novum" [Cantus ID: 006617z.1]; "Audivi vocem de caelo tamquam" [Cantus ID: 006153]; back flyeaf and pastedown: "Isti sunt sancti qui non" [Cantus ID: 007021]; Ambulabunt mecum in albis [Cantus ID: 001364]; Hi sunt qui cum mulieribus" [Cantus ID: 003044]; Ambulabunt mecum in albis [Cantus ID: 001364]; "Isti sunt qui non inquinaverunt" [Cantus ID: 007021]; "Adoraverunt viventem in" [Cantus ID: 006050]; "Et ceciderunt in conspectu" [Cantus ID: 006050b]; "Ecce vidi agnum stantem supra" [Cantus ID: 006617]. All margins are trimmed, with some loss of text. Initials in red with purple flourishing and blue with red flourishing. Written in Gothic rotunda, in 9 long lines and 9 four-line staffs. Ruled in lead, with double vertical bounding lines.|In good condition despite missing and damaged leaves. Lower margins of folios 2 and 175 excised, with no loss of text. Major imperfections on parchment and signs of early repairs, some of which are probably from when the parchment was prepared and some of which are by sewing. Leaves are of uneven sizes, with many leaves untrimmed and edges of skins present, especially on the fore-edge and the tail-edge. Ink smears on a number of leaves. Few marginal and interlinear corrections by a contemporary hand in a different ink. Marginal technical signs and annotations in lead throughout.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Charterhouse of Notre-Dame-du-Val-de-Bénédiction in Villeneuve-lès-Avignon, France (Chartreuse du Val de bénédiction). Two late medieval ownership inscriptions in ink: "Iste liber e[st] vallis b[e]n[e]dicc[i]o[n]is de villa nova ordinis Cartusien[sis] p[ro]pe Avinionem" in the lower margin on folio 71r and "Vallis benediccionis ord[in]is Ca[r]tusien[sis]" in the upper margin on folio 111r. Bookseller marks in pencil on front pastedown, including "Ms. 48" and a price. Initial "R" in brown crayon in upper right corner on back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 52 leaves : parchment ; 168 x 119 (120 x 83) mm bound to 170 x 120 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: 52 (parchment) + i (parchment, pastedown): 1¹² + 2¹² (2 and 11 are singletons) + 3-4¹² + 5⁴.|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner on folios 12v, 24v, 36v, 48v.|Layout: Written in 24 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, now mostly erased.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica textualis.|Decoration: Initials in plain red throughout (one initial I skipped on folio 9v, one initial C corrected to K on folio 36v); guide letters visible in outer margins on most folios.|Binding: Romanesque, possibly original. Bound in full dark brown leather over wooden boards, with three alum-tawed slit straps laced through channels. Blind-tooling on front and back cover. Remnants of three paper labels adhered to the head, middle and tail of spine, perhaps as an earlier preservation measure. Most of the leather is destroyed, the spine is exposed and both boards are detached. Evidence of a closure structure and chain sites on the boards; all closure and chain components are missing. Remnants of a title in ink on leather on head of front cover; inscription now effaced and damaged, illegible except for the word "Cronica."|Origin: Probably written in Central Europe or Italy in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS B90|In good condition except for some minor water damage on lower fore-edge. Signs of early repairs of parchment defects on several folios. Notes in black ink in a modern hand in upper margin of folio 1r ("M[anu]s[criptu]s inceptum anno Christi 1217 vel ad summum 1220") and in upper margin of back pastedown ("Hoc m[anu]s[criptu]s absolutum est circa annum d[omi]ni 1272 vel 1273"). A short note by a Theodoricus, Dean of St Mary's at Aachen (today Aachen Cathedral) added by a later hand in lower margin of folio 52v.|The manuscript contains an expanded version of Gilbert of Rome's Chronicon pontificum et imperatorum Romanorum with interpolations from other texts, possibly from Martin of Opava's Chronicon pontificum et imperatorum or one or more of its sources.|History of the manuscript is unknown. Title, possibly original, on front cover [see binding]. Inscribed "XI.4" in black ink on inside of front board. Scraped off (ownership?) inscription and an unidentified signature in lower margin on folio 1r. Inscribed "C.8" (?) in red crayon on back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 11 leaves : parchment ; 235 x 164 (115-125 x 180-190) mm bound to 245 x 173 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (modern paper, i is pastedown, ii and iii are adhered to each other) + 11 (parchment) + liv (modern paper, lii and liii are adhered to each other, liv is pastedown): 1¹⁰ + 1 leaf after 9. Folio 8bis[bis] is a parchment slip sewn on the inner margin of folio [8bis]v.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner, skipping one folio after 8 (1-8, [8bis], 8bis[bis], 9).|Layout: Written in 22-30 long lines, above top line. Ruled in lead and ink, partly with full-length vertical bounding lines. Pricking marks visible on fore-edge margins.|Script: Written by at least three hands in Praegothica (hand 1: folio 1v; hand 2: folios 2r-[8bis]v; hand 3: folios [8bis]v-9v).|Decoration: 2-line initial G in plain green on folio 1v; 2- to 4-line initials in plain red in the rest of the manuscript; rubrics in green (only on folio 1v) and red; sentence initials occasionally highlighted in red.|Binding: Modern, nineteenth century. Bound in full paper dyed in green over paper boards. Gold-tooling on spine; title areas are of leather dyed in light brown and onlaid. Marbled endleaves.|Origin: Probably written at the Abbey of Saint-Sulpice-en-Bugey in the last third of the twelfth century, after 1165.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C212|In moderate condition, with edges of parchment leaves fragile and damaged. Some loss of text due to damage on the edges of leaves and because of corroded green ink on the first folio. Editorial annotations in pencil and pen by at least two hands. Offset of a printed text in two columns bearing the title "Histoire de la Bastille" visible on the verso of the last leaf of each gathering in the back flyleaves.|The manuscript probably comes from the library of the Abbey of Saint-Sulpice-en-Bugey near Thézillieu in Ain, France and seems to have stayed in the region until the end of the nineteenth century. From the collection of Edmond Révérend du Mesnil: two of his bookplates of different sizes pasted on front and back pastedowns, which both read: "Deo reverandus et legi / Bibliothèque de M. E. Révérend du Mesnil." Bookseller marks in pencil on front and back flyleaves, some of which are erased.

physical_description: Extent: 303 leaves : parchment, illuminations, portraits, coat of arms ; 348 x 230 (235 x 145) mm bound to 360 x 235 mm
note: Title from closing rubric on folio 303r.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iv (modern paper, i is pastedown, ii and iii are adhered to each other) + 303 (parchment) + iv (modern paper, ii and iii are adhered to each other, iv is pastedown): 1-30¹⁰ + 31¹⁰ (wants 3-8, 10).|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in lower right corner (2-302, skipping folio 4), crossed out and corrected on the last folio of each gathering. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed B-I, K-Z, AA-GG in pencil at center in lower margin on the recto of first folio of each gathering beginning with the second quire and leaves of last quire signed HH1, HH2, HH9 in pencil at center in lower margin on the recto side of leaves by Alexandra Mason, June 1963.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in frames in lower right corner on folios 10v, 20v, 30v, 40v, 50v, 60v, 70v, 80v, 90v, 100v, 110v, 120v, 130v, 140v, 150v, 160v, 170v, 180v, 190v, 200v, 210v, 220v, 230v, 240v, 150v, 160v, 270v, 280v, 290v, 300v.|Layout: Written in 41 long lines, above top line. Ruled in lead, with double vertical bounding lines. Pricking marks occasionally visible in lower margins.|Script: Written by Walterus de Valle in Humanistic bookhand.|Decoration: 8-line anthropomorphic initial G in purple, red, green, blue and yellow on gold background, depicting St Augustine holding a book and a scepter at the beginning of Book I on folio 15r; 4- to 12-line foliate initials in purple, red, green, blue and yellow on gold background at the beginning of the rest of the twenty-one books on folios 26r, 36v, 47v, 58v, 71v, 79v, 91r, 103r, 110r, 124v, 135v, 145v, 155r, 167v, 182r, 199v, 213v, 235r, 249v, 269v, 286r; 2- to 3-line initials at the beginning of chapters in blue with red, dark red or purple flourishing or in red with purple flourishing throughout; spaces left for initials on folios 15r and 105r; full foliate border with arms on folio 15r; running titles in red and blue in upper margins indicating book numbers; most rubrics in red; guide letters visible for the most part.|Binding: Modern. Bound in half leather dyed dark green and marbled paper boards. Six raised bands. Marbled endleaves.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in mid-fifteenth century by Walterus de Valle [also known as Gualtiero della Valle]: "Walterus de Valle scripsit" -- colophon, folio 303r.|Former shelfmark: MS Z19|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS G1|In good condition except for missing leaves. Early repairs on parchment, some of which are probably from when the parchment was prepared. Contemporary corrections and annotations, including nota signs, manicules and brackets by at least two hands. Some of the marginal annotations in outer margins are cut out due to trimming of the leaves.|From the collection of Matteo Barresi, marquis of Pietraperzia, Italy: coat of arms with the shield of the Barresi family (or, two pales vair, flanked by two angels, below which are a pair of blackbirds in profile, facing outward) on folio 15r and ownership inscription on folio 303r: "Ex bibliotheca p[er] ill[ustrissimum] d[omnium] Don Mattheum de Barresio facta anno [Christi] 1531." The shield of the Baressi family on folio 15r is painted over another shield, partially visible to the naked eye on the verso of the leaf; unidentified. Unidentified sixteenth-century ownership inscription and signature by the same hand: "Iste liber e[st] mey" in lower margin on folio 1r and "Iste liber e[st] mey [...] de? [...] hamoy?" in upper margin on folio 14v. Signature of Paolo Gallo (late sixteenth or early seventeenth century) in lower margin on folio 1r: "F. Paulus Gallus re[visor?]." Modern history of the manuscript is unknown.

subject_as_recorded: Augustine, of Hippo, Saint, 354-430. Regula--Commentaries|Manuscripts, Medieval|Manuscripts, Medieval--Kansas--Lawrence|Manuscripts, Latin|Monasticism and religious orders--Rules--Early works to 1800

physical_description: Extent: 158 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 237 x 158 (340 x 245) mm bound to 348 x 245 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iii (modern paper, i and ii are pastedowns) + 158 (parchment) + iii (modern paper, ii and iii are pastedowns): 1² + 2-19⁸ + 20-21⁶.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1, 1a, 2-157).|Signatures: Quires two to thirteen signed a-c, e, d, f-i, k-m, with the first half of the leaves in each quire also signed 1-4 in lower right corner of the recto side of leaves; signature q present on folio 114r and t (?) on folio 138r. Rest of the leaf signatures may have been lost due to trimming.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner on folios 9v, 17v, 25v, 33v, 41v, 49v, 57v, 65v, 73v, 81v, 89v, 97v, 105v, 113v, 121v, 129v, 137v, 145v, 151v.|Watermarks: Single watermark on the front and back flyleaves: reads "G. Fichtners Nachf."|Layout: Written in two columns of 48 lines, below top line. Frame ruled in two columns in lead and ink, with single vertical and double horizontal bounding lines. There is an unused, third horizontal bounding line in the upper margin on several leaves. Pricking marks visible on the outer margins of most leaves.|Script: Written by a single hand in Netherlandish Hybrida Libraria.|Decoration: 9-line puzzle initial A and 10-line puzzle initial C in red and blue with foliate pen-flourishing in red, violet and green, developing into partial borders on folios 2ra and 23rb respectively; 6-line initial H and 7-line initial D in blue with foliate pen-flourishing in red and green on folios 3vb and 21va respectively; 2- to 7-line initials in alternating plain red and blue at the beginning of chapters; 1-line initials in in alternating plain red and blue at the beginning of each line of the table of contents on folios 21va-23rb; sentence initials highlighted in red; paragraph marks in alternating red and blue; rubrics in red; words and phrases underlined in red. Guide letters visible to the left of or under the initials on most leaves.|Binding: Modern, eighteenth century. Bound in dark brown quarter leather and paste paper in brown patterns over wooden boards. Wooden boards may originate from the contemporary binding of the manuscript. Five raised bands. Blind-tooling on spine, featuring a six-petal flower between each raised band except for the title area at the head of spine, between the first and second raised bands. Evidence of a closure structure, most likely two fore-edge clasps hinging from the back board, with all components lost. Binding is worn, especially on the corners and along the spine, with the paste paper heavily damaged.|Origin: Probably written in the Netherlands, possibly North Holland in the second half of the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS Z39|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E36|In good condition. Outer half of the second leaf (folio 1a) is excised with no loss of text. Minor water damage in the upper margin of last two leaves. Pastedowns as well as the recto of the first leaf and the verso of the final leaf are stained from leather turn-ins. Parchment stubs (possibly excised former flyleaves) at the beginning and end of the text block. Minor imperfections on parchment throughout and signs of early repairs, including evidence of repairs by sewing. Most small holes in parchment framed in red. Leather tabs adhered to the fore-edges of leaves, corresponding to folios 2, 4, 23. A series of contemporary corrections and additions, either by erasure or by use of technical signs. Nota bene and exemplum signs throughout, most of which seem to be by the scribe and most of which are highlighted in red.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Unidentified ownership inscription in ink in upper left corner on front pastedown: "No: 3 H. J. von Ausjem" (?). Bookseller marks in pencil on front pastedown, including "Ms. 224". Initial "R" in brown crayon in upper right corner on back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 25 leaves : paper, illuminations, maps, charts ; 295 x 261 (110-125 x 65) mm
note: Title supplied by cataloger.|Manuscript gatherings|Collation: 25 (paper): 1 leaf + 1-2¹².|Foliation: Two sets of modern foliation in pencil: in lower left corner (1-24, beginning with the second folio) and in upper right corner (1-25). The description follows the modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchword in lower right on folio 13v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks: a letter M (found only on folio 1; similar to Briquet BR 8346); a tower with battlements, a door and a window (very similar to Piccard IT8355-PO-101143).|Layout: Part 1: Written in 29 long lines. Unruled. Part 2: Written in 24 long lines, above top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length double vertical bounding lines and full-length single horizontal bounding line in the upper margin.|Script: Written by two hands in Humanistic cursive (folio 1r) and Humanistic minuscule (folios 2r-25r).|Part 1: No decoration. Part 2: 15 circular geographical and astrological diagrams, including two mappae mundi on folios 2v, 3r, 3v, 6r, 6v, 8v, 10v, 14r, 15v; portolan-style maps of the Mediterranean Sea, the Aegean Sea and the Black Sea featuring mostly ports and coastal cities in the Near East, North Africa and southern Europe on folios 16r, 17r, 20r, 20v, 21r, 21v, 22r, 22v, 23r, 23v, 24r, 24v, 25r; drawing of the tower of Babel on folio 18r. 3-line spaces left for initials for the first stanza on each folio and 1-line spaces left for initials for the second and third stanzas; guide letters visible for the most part, which might have been inserted by a hand other than that of the main text, with a number of initials filled in by later hands. Rubrics in brown by a hand other than that of the main text. Labels of diagrams and maps in brown by a hand other than that of the main text.|Binding: Unbound.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the third quarter of the fifteenth century. It is possible that the original manuscript was completed around or just after 1463, based on a colophon on folio 18r in Notre Dame, University of Notre Dame, Hesburgh Library, cod. Lat. c. 11, which constitutes part of the same manuscript.|Former shelfmarks: Phillipps MS 3542 and MS E88|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, Pryce MS P4|Related shelfmark: Notre Dame, University of Notre Dame, Hesburgh Library, cod. Lat. c. 11|In fragile condition, with significant water and bookworm damage. Edges frayed and brittle. Upper left corner of folio 1 is torn, with no loss of text. Ink bleed on folios 2-25. Signs of early repairs throughout. Initials, rubrics and labels of diagrams and maps are added later or by different hands. Remnants of a shed snakeskin, perhaps used as a bookmark, between folios 23v and 24r. Manicules on folios 11r and 14v.|Previously, Pryce MS P4 was part of a larger manuscript; the other part is now Notre Dame, University of Notre Dame, Hesburgh Library, Lat. c. 11 (39 folios). As it stands, Pryce MS P4 is a composite manuscript, consisting of two parts: Part 1 consists of folio 1 and Part 2 folios 2-25. Part 1 could have been a flyleaf of the original manuscript, or an added leaf.|The copy of La sfera in this manuscript contains all four books: Book I occupies folios 2r-7v, Book II folios 8r-13v, Book III folios 14r-19v and Book IV folios 20r-25r. Only the beginnings of Book II and Book III are signaled in the manuscript in the upper margins of folio 8r and folio 14r respectively. Book IV is missing the fourth, fifth and sixth stanzas due to a scribal error or a defective exemplar.|The copy of La sfera in this manuscript was transcribed by a team of ten scholars (Isabella Bolognese, Marguerite Bordry, Karen Severud Cook, Alyssa Granacki, Sunny Harrison, Liz Hebbard, Laura Ingallinella, Monica Keane, Agnieszka Rec, N. Kıvılcım Yavuz, in alphabetical order by last name) during "La Sfera Challenge," a digital transcription project that took place in summer 2020. The open access transcription is made available as part of: Laura Morreale, Monica Keane, and Benjamin L. Albritton. "La Sfera Challenge Project 1st Edition (september 2020) Archiving Dossier Narrative." BodoArXiv. September 10, 2020. DOI:10.34055/osf.io/4ghzu.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Reported to be from the collection of Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 3542) but there is no ownership mark of Phillipps on the manuscript. No. 3542 listed under "Longman" in The Phillipps Manuscripts contains many items described as "papers and letters from the Office of the Minister of Finance under Emperor Napoleon" with no identifiable reference to this manuscript. Purchased by H. P. Kraus in the 1966 Sotheby's sale, when the manuscript was listed as having 64 leaves. The remaining portion of this manuscript is now Notre Dame, University of Notre Dame, Hesburgh Library, cod. Lat. c. 11, sold to them in September 1967 also by H. P. Kraus. Possible bookseller marks in pencil: inscribed "prelim" in lower left corner on folio 1r and "9504" in lower right corner on folio 25v.

physical_description: Extent: 180 leaves : paper, charts ; 305 x 215 (215-237 x 136-155) mm bound to 315 x 215 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript composite codex|Collation: i (paper) + 180 (paper): 1-13¹² + 14¹⁴ + 15¹² (wants 11, 12, possibly blank)|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1-180), completed on April 6, 1921, according to a note on verso of front flyleaf.|Signatures: Quires signed 1-15 in red at center in lower margin on the recto of first folio of each gathering by a contemporary hand, possibly one of the rubricators.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in ink by multiple hands in different positions in lower right corner on folios 48v, 60v (in red), 72v (underlined in red), 84v (in red), 108v, 120v, 132v, 144v, 156v, 170v.|Watermarks: Part 1: Single watermark: a horn (similar to Piccard PPO 7-6-54). Part 2: Single watermark: a horn (similar to what is found in Part 1). Part 3: Single watermark: a horn (similar to what is found in Part 1 and possibly the same with that of Part 2). Part 4: Single watermark: a bull's head with no facial features with a single-line shaft above surmounted by a cross (similar to WZIS DE4200-Donaueschingen296_16).|Layout: Part 1: Written in 42-43 long lines, above top line. Frame ruled in lead, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Part 2: Written in two columns of 43 lines. Unruled except for full-length vertical bounding lines for both columns ruled in ink. Part 3: Written in two columns of 51 lines, above top line. Frame ruled in ink in two columns, with full-length vertical and horizontal bounding lines. Part 4: Written in 45-54 long lines, above top line. Frame ruled in lead, with no horizontal line in the lower margin.|Script: Written by multiple hands in Gothic cursive.|Decoration: Part 1: 3-line initials in plain red; paragraph marks in red; sentence initials highlighted in red; marginal rubrics in red; some phrases and rubrics underlined in red; guide letters visible to the left of the initials. Part 2: 2- to 3-line initials in plain red; sentence initials highlighted in red; some rubrics underlined in red; guide letters visible underneath the initials. Part 3: 2- to 3-line initials in plain red, some of which are supplied incorrectly; 3-line space left for an initial on folio 33vb; sentence initials highlighted in red; some guide letters visible to the left of the initials. Part 4: diagrams in ink of consanguinity and affinity on folios 176v-180r; 2- to 3-line initials in plain red; sentence initials and paragraph marks highlighted in red; marginal rubrics in red; phrases underlined in red; nota bene and questio signs in red or highlighted in red; guide letters visible to the left of the initials.|Binding: Fifteenth century, possibly original. Bound in full alum-tawed leather over wooden boards, with three paired single sewing supports and two integral endbands at head and tail (Kapitalbünde) made of cords laced through channels, frayed and adhered to the insides of both boards and secured with wooden pegs. V-shaped notches cut into the turn-ins. Four transverse spine linings made of parchment adhered to the inside of each board. Two fore-edge clasps hinging from the back cover and catching onto two lipped catchplates nailed into shallow recesses on the front board. The strap is a laminate of two layers of leather dyed blue with an inner lining of leather. Three rectangular paper labels adhered to the spine: the two at the head, which include the title, are heavily damaged and illegible, the one at the tail, also partly damaged, reads "348" in red. Minor wear and damage to the binding, with the lower clasp missing. Repurposed parchment text guards offset onto the insides of both boards, with both fragments excised and missing.|Origin: All four parts probably written at the Charterhouse Aula Beatae Mariae in Buxheim, Germany in the second quarter of the fifteenth century. Part 2 written by Brother Johannes and completed in 1437: "P[er] me Ioh[ann]em fr[atre]m scriptu[m] a[n]no d[omi]ni 1437." -- colophon, folio 24vb.|Former shelfmark: MS Z38|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E35|Related shelfmark: Berlin, Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin - Preussischer Kulturbesitz, Ms. lat. qu. 372|MS E35 contains copies of a number of anonymous or hitherto unidentified works. Item 3 is based on the Quodlibeta by Henry of Ghent. Item 4 is based on the Sententiarum libri IV by Peter Lombard. Items 5 and 6, titled here De consangunitate and De arbore affinitatis respectively, as well as the succeeding diagrams are based on the Super arboribus consanguinitatis et affinitatis by Giovanni d'Andrea.|MS E35 is a composite manuscript, consisting of four parts: Part 1 consists of folios 1-12, Part 2 folios 13-24, Part 3 folios 25-36, Part 4 folios 37-180.|Dimensions of written area: Part 1: 225 x 136 mm; Part 2: 220 x 147-155 mm; Part 3: 215 x 142-145 mm; Part 4: 220-237 x 145 mm|In good condition. Evidence of repurposed parchment text guards folded around the first and last gatherings, with stubs present and offset onto the insides of both boards, with text visible which remain unidentified. Both fragments are excised and missing. Evidence of a paper text-hook flyleaf, which might have been pasted on to the front board, with its stub also present preceding the parchment text guard stub at the end of the first gathering. Remnants of paper (potentially pastedowns) on turn-ins on the insides of both boards. The center-folds of all gatherings are supported by approximately 14 mm parchment strips that are adhered to the innermost leaves of each quire. The parchment strips are all repurposed fragments, possibly from the same manuscript, with text which remain unidentified. Folios 71 and 72 are torn on the fore-edge, with no loss of text. Deckle edges visible on the tail-edge in Part 4. Few marginal corrections by contemporary hands.|The manuscript comes from the library of the Charterhouse Aula Beatae Mariae in Buxheim near Memmingen, Germany (Reichskartause Buxheim). Ownership inscription in the upper margin on folio 1r: "Buxheim" with a preceding encircled cross. Eighteenth-century label of the library with the contemporary shelfmark of the manuscript adhered to tail of spine: "348." MS E35 is probably the same volume which is listed under letter B, number 12 in the earliest register of the library dated to the mid-fifteenth century, Berlin, Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin - Preussischer Kulturbesitz, Ms. lat. qu. 372, folio 17r. After the secularization of the Buxheim Charterhouse in 1802/1803, the estate along with the library passed on to private hands; first to the Counts of Ostein and then to those of Waldbott von Bassenheim. Carthusians remained on site until 1812. The holdings of the library was auctioned off in Munich in 1883 by Carl Förster and in 1884 and 1885 by Ludwig Rosenthal, who had also purchased most of Förster's stock. The manuscript was listed for sale by Ludwig Rosenthal at least on two occasions, first in 1885 and later in 1910. It is not known whether the manuscript changed hands or remained in the Rosenthal family for nearly 75 years. In 1959, the manuscript was listed for sale by Bernard Rosenthal, Ludwig Rosenthal's grandnephew, from whom the University of Kansas acquired the manuscript. Bookseller marks in pencil on recto of front flyleaf by different hands, including "Ms. 212," "Nider 14323" and a price. Table of contents in pencil on verso of front flyleaf by a modern hand, presumably Ludwig Rosenthal or one of his associates, dated April 6, 1921. Initial "R" in brown crayon in upper right corner on inside of back board.

physical_description: Extent: 221 leaves : paper, illuminations; 200 x 130 (164 x 105) mm bound to 218 x 142 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (modern paper, i is pastedown) + 221 (paper) + ii (modern paper, ii is pastedown): 1-21¹⁰ +22¹² (wants 12, possibly blank).|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed a-i, k-t, v, x-y, with leaves foliated 1-10 in each quire but some are lost due to trimming on the tail-edge and fore-edge. Signatures present on the recto of leaves in lower right corner are: a3, b[1], b2, c2, c[5], g[5], l1, l2, l[4], l[5], m3, n[1], o1, p[1], p[4], q[5], t1, t3, v[2], v[3], v4, v[5], x[2], y1.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right on folios 10v, 20v, 30v, 50v, 60v, 80v, 130v, 140v, 150v, 160v, 170v, 180v, 190v, 200v,  210v. The manuscript probably had catchwords throughout but the rest are lost due to trimming on the tail-edge.|Watermarks: Single watermark on the front flyleaf: a majuscule letter A with an unidentified motif (only half of watermark is extant; unidentified); single watermark in the textblock: a triple mound (similar to Briquet BR 11652); single watermark on the back flyleaf: a majuscule letter C with an unidentified motif (only half of watermark is extant; unidentified).|Layout: Written in 33 long lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length vertical bounding lines and a full-length horizontal bounding line in the upper margin.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic rotunda.|Decoration: 9-line initial M in gold with a partial white vine-stem border in burgundy, green and blue at the beginning of Book I on folio 2r; 4- to 5-line boxed initials in gold on various combinations of burgundy, purple, green and blue backgrounds with fine scrollwork in white at the beginning of the rest of the books on folios 30r, 53v, 82r, 110r, 132r, 160r, 185r, 204r; 2- to 5-line initials at the beginning of chapters in plain blue; paragraph marks in blue; most rubrics in pink with some words in blue throughout; chapter numbers in Hindu-Arabic numerals in tables of contents in pink; guide letters visible to the left of the initials.|Binding: Modern. Bound in full leather dyed in dark red (Morocco) over paper boards; rebacked with leather dyed in light brown. Gold-tooled with two concentric frames and a flower in the middle encircled with stars. The outer frame consists of a band of birds and branches and the inner frame is a narrower band of harps and flowers with eagles on its four corners. The head-, tail- and fore-edge of covers are also gold-tooled and there is gold-tooling on spine. Five false raised bands. Stuck-on endband linings made of textile. Minor damage around the corners and spine-folds.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS BK Z18|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E18|In good condition. Minor staining and foxing on a number of leaves. Both pastedowns are torn along the spine-fold. The center-folds are supported by approximately 10 mm parchment strips that are adhered to the innermost leaves of each gathering. In the first and last gatherings there are also approximately 10 mm parchment strips adhered to the spine-folds of the outermost leaves. Deckle edges are visible on the tail-edge of a number of folios. Few marginal corrections and rubrics, mostly by the scribe. Rubrics added in red on folio 86v.|In this manuscript the works of Lactantius are devised as nine books, with the first seven corresponding to the Divinae Institutiones, the eighth to the De ira Dei and the ninth to the De opificio Dei. Each of the books of the Divinae Institutiones as well as the De ira Dei and the De opificio Dei are preceded by a table of contents. Spaces are left for the passages in Greek in all of the works, some of which are marked with the letter "g" in the margins.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Unidentified coat of arms or an institutional stamp on folio 1r, now erased. Unidentified inscription, possibly belonging to a previous owner, on folio 2r, now erased. Possible bookseller marks: inscribed "No 2" in pencil in the upper left corner of the verso of front flyleaf; "21635" in pencil in lower left corner of the recto of back flyleaf; "no 74" in pencil in the upper right corner and "43809" (?) in blue crayon in the lower half of the verso of back flyleaf.

physical_description: Extent: 67 leaves : paper ; 290 x 220 (198 x 104) mm bound to 303 x 226 mm
note: Title from opening rubric on folio 1r, added later.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iii (modern paper, i is pastedown, iii is glued piece of paper on a stubbed leaf) + 67 (paper) + ii (modern paper, ii is pastedown): collation formula is indeterminable due to heavy repairs and artificially conjoined leaves; approximately 20 leaves are missing at the beginning and as many are missing from the first part of the manuscript.|Foliation: Modern pagination in pencil in upper right corner (1-136, beginning with the third flyleaf and only on the recto leaves until 136). Modern foliation in pencil at middle in upper margin (1, 2, 6, 37, 50, 61). Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Watermarks: There are five watermarks. A vertical horn (similar to Briquet BR 7643); a vertical bow and arrow (similar to Briquet BR 786); a cross rising over triple mounds (similar to Briquet BR 11681); a crescent surmounted by a cross (similar to Briquet BR 5276); a vertical pair of scissors (similar to Briquet BR 3667).|Layout: Written in 29-36 long lines, below top line until 40v, above top line from 41r. Ruled in lead.|Script: Written by several hands in Gothic rotunda (until folio 41v) and early Humanistic script (from folio 41v). There is a clear change of hands on folio 41v, line 10.|Decoration: Space left for 3- to 4-line initials on folios 37r, 49v, 50r, 61r.|Binding: Modern. Bound in half calfskin and blue cloth by George Bretherton, possibly for Sir Thomas Phillipps. Binder's ticket on the top left corner of the front pastedown: "BRETHERTON, ligavit 1847." Blind- and gold-tooling on the spine. Paper label adhered to the tail of spine and annotations in ink on spine.|Origin: Probably written in Italy during the first quarter of the fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 12281|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E71|In relatively good condition, despite loss of several leaves. Heavy repairs on the remaining leaves, presumably made during the rebinding of the manuscript in the mid-nineteenth century. Top of spine (approximately 50 mm) above spine title is broken off and missing. Recto of inserted stub (folio iii) includes a nineteenth-century note on the contents. Heavy marginal and interlinear annotations throughout by different hands. Unidentified signature in red crayon on the upper margin of folio 5v. Manicules on folios 6r, 7v, 8r, 12v, 13r, 20r, 20v, 25v, 34r, 35v.|The copy of the Aeneid in this manuscript includes 11-line commentaries at the beginning of each book. Only the beginnings of Book VII (folio 37r), Book VIII (folio 49v) and Book IX (folio 61r) are present.|Early history of the manuscript is uncertain. The manuscript was purchased from Payne & Foss by Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 12281) in 1848 (or 1847). It is inscribed "Phillipps MS 12281" in ink on folio 1r. Listed as no. 12281/22 under "Payne & Foss, 1848" and reported to have come from the Abbey of Santo Stefano in Fossanova ("ex Abb. S. Stephani de, Nova Fossa") in The Phillipps Manuscripts. The Fossanova provenance is contested and uncertain. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. This manuscript was probably among those inherited; however, there is no known record of it in the subsequent sales from the Phillipps library. There is a spiked round paper label adhered to the tail of spine that belongs to an unidentified owner with a handwritten inscription: "S II F // Virgilius [underlined] // Ms. XV // fol. 20400." Inscription by a different, modern hand in ink on spine, below gold-tooled title: "1200/1300 Approx 1300." Possible bookseller marks in pencil on the flyleaves; three modern inscriptions on front flyleaf, now erased: "Virgilius Aeneid (early) 15th c. #220," "ca. 1460-70," "No. 111" and one modern inscription in lower margin of first back flyleaf: "4000." Unidentified signature in red crayon in upper margin of folio 5v. From the collection of Robert T. Aitchison, who purchased the manuscript from Bernard M. Rosenthal in July 1961. Aitchison's bookplate is pasted on front pastedown; annotations about the date of the manuscript in ink on the bookplate, possibly by him.

Bound in half parchment and paste paper with vertical stripes in cream and dark blue.|Origin: Probably written in Italy during the twelfth century.|Former shelfmark: MS BK Z23|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E22.|In good condition except for soiling and discoloration, especially on the outermost leaves. Possible bookseller or ownership inscriptions in pencil in upper and lower margins of folio 1r, now erased and illegible.

subject: http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008422|http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008422;http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1212060|http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1008395|http://id.worldcat.org/fast/1096982
physical_description: Extent: 82 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 309 x 219 (165 x 95) mm bound to 320 x 225 mm
note: Title from spine (added later): "Cicero Rhetorica Ms Saec XIV"|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (parchment) + 82 (parchment) + ii (parchment): 1-8¹⁰ + 9².|Foliation: Two sets of modern foliation in pencil: in lower left corner (2-84; begins with 2 on folio 1r and ends on first back flyleaf) and in upper right corner (1-82). The description follows the modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords at center on folios 10v, 20v, 30v, 40v, 50v, 60v, 70v, 80v.|Layout: Written in 23 long lines, below top line. Ruled in light brown/red ink, with inner and outer vertical bounding lines in lead.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothic rotunda.|Decoration: A 5-line foliate initial E with a three-quarter foliate border on folio 1r; 1- to 3-line initials in red with red penwork, blue with red penwork, plain red or plain blue; paragraph marks in alternating red and blue; empty shield on folio 1r; space left for decoration on folio 12v.|Binding: Modern. Bound in 1931 by Douglas Cockerell & Son for Charles Stephen Ascherson. Debossed binder's name in middle of tail edge of inside back cover: "D. C. & Son 1931." Bound in full brown leather with two concentric gold- and blind-tooled frames and a circle in middle. Five raised bands. Green endbands. Parchment doublures on inside covers are lifting.|Origin: Probably written in Italy in the early fifteenth century.|Former shelfmark: MS BK Z17|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS E17|In good condition except for some minor water damage on the fore-edge, especially in the last three quires. The beginnings of books are signaled by a later hand in upper margins ("liber secu[n]dus" on folios 12v and 13r; "lib[er] [tertius]" on folios 33v and 34r; "lib[er] [quartus]" on folio 48r). Very few contemporary corrections, possibly by the scribe themself.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. From the collection of Charles Stephen Ascherson: his bookplate pasted on inside of front cover, reading "Ex Libris C. S. Ascherson" in capital letters. The manuscript was purchased by Ascherson at the 1931 Sotheby's sale: purchase recorded on upper part of bookplate in pencil: "Sotheby London [?] 17.2.1931." The manuscript was later offered for sale by Bernard Quaritch in 1946, 1951 and again in 1952. Possible bookseller marks in pencil on recto of first front flyleaf: a boxed in lot/inventory number "735" in lower left corner, an encircled "2" in upper right corner and a price at center. Bookseller marks on recto of first back flyleaf: Bernard Quaritch inventory number "19297" in lower left corner, Bernard Quaritch price in code "C]S/÷" in upper right corner as well as a collation formula at center.

material_as_recorded: parchment, illuminations, frontispiece, coat of arms
physical_description: Extent: 38 leaves : parchment, illuminations, frontispiece, coat of arms ; 228 x 156 (170 x 105) mm bound to 236 x 164 mm
note: Title from opening rubric on folio 5r.|Manuscript codex|Collation: 38 (parchment, 1 and 38 are pastedowns): 1⁴ (1 is pastedown) + 2-4⁸ + 5⁸ (wants 8, possibly blank) + 6⁴ (wants 3, possibly blank; 4 is pastedown).|Foliation: Original (?) pagination (1-62), beginning with quire 2, on folio 5r. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower right corner of the text frame on folios 6v, 7v, 8v, 10v, 12v, 14v, 20v, 28v.|Layout: Written in 21 long lines, above top line. Ruled in lead; written area also marked with a full frame in red.|Script: Written by a single hand in Humanistic cursive.|Decoration: A decorated frontispiece on folio 4v with the coat of arms of Dominicus Capranica, which later became the coat of arms of the Almo Collegio Capranica that was founded in 1457 in Rome, Italy (charged with an anchor tied to a hawser intertwined around three uprooted Cypress trees on a golden field and adorned with a cross bottony and a red galero with six tassels in three rows on each side); a decorated 4-line initial C on folio 5r; a 2-line initial D in red and gold and a line filler on folio 7v. The end of the text on folio 35v is arranged as a tailpiece (an inverted triangle, with the margins gradually increasing).|Binding: Early modern. Contemporary to the manuscript, possibly original, probably made in the mid-sixteenth century in a workshop in Rome, Italy. Bound in full leather dyed dark red, gold-tooled with wide floral frames made by a panel stamp and featuring painted shield of Dominicus Capranica at the center of both covers. Five raised bands. Gold-tooling on spine, with title area dyed light brown. Gold-tooled frames on the covers are the same with those of Plate 58 in Geoffrey D. Hobson. Maioli, Canevari and Others (Boston, MA: Little, Brown, and Company, 1926). Six printed (?) paper (?) strips adhered to the spine to reinforce the attachment of the cover to the bookblock are partly visible underneath pastedowns on both sides. Signs of early repairs on corners and head and tail of spine. Two paper labels adhered to tail of spine: a round label with a handwritten number "1230" and a rectangular label, placed partly on top of the other, with a typeset number "8274" [see provenance].|Origin: Probably written in Rome, Italy in mid-sixteenth century.|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 8274|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C247|In relatively good condition despite water damage and staining on the first few leaves and ink smears on a few leaves. Staining on pastedowns from turn-ins. Frontispiece exhibits extensive abrasion and some pigment loss. Very few corrections. Doodle of a man with a sword on the lower half of folio 36r.|The manuscript perhaps originally was commissioned by a member of the Capranica family or by the library of the Almo Collegio Capranica in Rome, based on the frontispiece with the coat of arms of Dominicus Capranica and the binding featuring his shield. Soon after, in the second half of the sixteenth century, the manuscript was probably in the possession of Rinaldo Ridolfini, a lawyer in Perugia, Italy, based on an inscription on folio 2r: "Ranaldus Ridolfinus." The manuscript was purchased in Perugia in 1822 by Frederick North, the 5th Earl of Guildford: his bookplate pasted on front pastedown (folio 1v) and two almost identical inscriptions, presumably by him: "e libris F. Com. de Guilford empt. Perusia A. D. 1822" on folio 1v and "e libris Friderici Com. de Guilford empt. Perusia AD. 1822" on folio 2r. The manuscript was later in the collection of Richard Heber, presumably acquired in the 1830 auction of Frederick North's manuscripts by R. H. Evans. There is a round paper label with a handwritten number "1230" adhered to the tail of the spine; 1230 was the lot number of this manuscript in the 1836 auction of Heber's manuscripts. The manuscript was purchased by Payne & Foss for Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 8274) in the 1836 auction of Heber's manuscripts. It is inscribed "8274" in blue crayon on folio 2r and there is a rectangular Phillipps label with a typeset number "8274" adhered to tail of spine. The manuscript is also inscribed "Heber" in pencil on folio 1v by Sir Thomas Phillipps. Listed as no. 8274/1230 under "Heber Mss" in The Phillipps Manuscripts. The manuscript was auctioned by Sotheby & Co. in 1968 and was purchased by Hofmann & Freeman Antiquarian Booksellers.

former_owner_label: Richard Heber|Thomas Thorpe|Thomas Phillipps|Katherine Somerset Wyttenbach Fenwick|Thomas FitzRoy Phillipps Fenwick|Harold Baillie Weaver|Thomas Gibson-Carmichael, 1st Baron Carmichael
physical_description: Extent: 190 leaves : paper ; 234 x 158 (160 x 85) mm bound to 239 x 165 mm
note: Title from spine (added later): "Martialis Epigrammata M.S. 1470"|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (modern paper, i is pastedown) + 190 (paper) + ii (modern paper, ii is pastedown): 1¹² + 2-18¹⁰ + 19¹⁰ (wants 9 and 10, possibly both blank).|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Vertical catchwords between the double vertical bounding lines on the right on folios 12v, 22v, 32v, 42v, 52v, 62v, 72v, 82v, 92v, 102v, 112v, 122v, 132v, 142v, 152v, 162v, 172v, 182v.|Watermarks: Two watermarks in the text-block: a detached crossbow with stirrup in a circle, with a single-lined arch and a double-lined shaft (unidentified); a triple mound from the middle of which rises a shaft surmounted by a star (very similar to Briquet BR 11752.)|Layout: Written in 31 long lines, above top line. Ruled in drypoint, with double inner and outer vertical bounding lines.|Script: Written by Jacopo Tiraboschi of Bergamo in Humanistic bookhand.|Decoration: Rubrics, including at the beginning of each poem, in red. Spaces left for 2- to 6-line initials. Guide letters visible throughout.|Binding: Modern. Repaired? by John P. Gray & Son Ltd. of Cambridge: binder's ink stamp in the lower left corner of the back pastedown. Quarter binding in brown leather over paper boards. Blind- and gold-tooling on spine. Three raised bands. Wear and tear on all edges as well as the spine. Damaged rectangular paper label adhered to the tail of spine.|Origin: Probably written in Bergamo, Italy and completed on October 19, 1470 by Jacopo Tiraboschi of Bergamo: "Iacobus Tirabuschus B[er]gomensis Artiu[m] Scolario MoccccoLxxo die decimo nono Octobris complevit hunc Marcialem" -- colophon, folio 184v.|Former shelfmark: MS Y20|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 9677|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS D2|In good condition despite bookworm damage throughout, especially near center-folds. Water damage (with no loss of text) on the lower part of the manuscript, especially worse in quires 17 to 19. The center-folds are supported by approximately 8 mm parchment or paper strips, some of which are repurposed, that are adhered to the innermost leaves of each gathering. Evidence of earlier repairs on paper. Few additions and corrections by a contemporary hand. Several numbers and short annotations inscribed in pencil on the front pastedown, now mostly erased. Annotations on folio 1r as well as a small piece of paper glued, with inscription in ink: "No. 28. Martial." Ownership inscriptions on folio 186v.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. In the early nineteenth century, the manuscript was first in the possession of Carlo Salvi and later in that of Luigi Celotti. According to Celotti's 1821 Sotheby's sale catalog, it came from either the collection of Matteo Luigi Canònici or that of Giovanni Saibante. The manuscript was later in the collection of Richard Heber, possibly purchased in Celotti's 1821 sale. It was then purchased by Thomas Thorpe in the 1836 auction of Heber's manuscripts. Ownership inscription on folio 186v: "Thomas Thorpe." Immediately after, also in 1836, the manuscript was purchased from Thomas Thorpe by Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 9677). It is inscribed "Phillipps MSS 9677" in ink at center on front pastedown and there are remnants of a rectangular Phillipps label with a typeset number, with only "96" remaining, adhered to the tail of spine. Listed as no. 9677 under "Thorpe Mss. 1836" in The Phillipps Manuscripts. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. Initials of Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick inscribed in upper left corner of verso of back flyleaf: "T.FF 1891." The manuscript was sold by Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick at a Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge sale in 1895. It seems to have been purchased by Harold Baillie-Weaver in the 1895 sale. The manuscript was later purchased by Bernard Quaritch from Harold Baillie-Weaver in a Christie, Manson & Woods sale in March 1898. It appears in two of Quaritch's sale catalogs, first immediately after their purchase in 1898 (Catalogue no. 180, item no. 40) and then in 1902 (Catalogue no. 211, item no. 153). The manuscript seems to have been purchased in 1902 by Sir Thomas Gibson-Carmichael, only to be sold a year later in a Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge sale of his collection. The manuscript is listed again in a sale catalog of Bernard Quaritch in 1905 (Catalogue no. 240, item no. 232), presumably repurchased in the 1903 Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge sale. However, only two years later, in 1907, it is again listed by Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge (June 24, 1907, item no. 714) and this time it is sold to another bookseller, Francis Edwards Ltd., who listed the manuscript in their catalog in 1909 (item no. 679). The manuscript was later in the possession of E. P. Goldschmidt, listed by them for sale several times beginning in 1930 (Catalogue no. 23, item no. 8) until 1955. Unidentified inscriptions, perhaps by different hands, on folio 186v: "Markham," "Maria" and "John." Possible bookseller marks, unidentified: several numbers and annotations on front pastedown; "tn?" inscribed in ink in upper right corner and "#11607" in pencil in lower right corner of back pastedown.

physical_description: Extent: 188 leaves : parchment, illuminations ; 268 x 190 (195 x 118) mm bound to 277 x 202 mm
note: Title from closing rubric on folio 188v.|Manuscript codex|Collation: iii (modern paper, i is pastedown) + 188 (parchment) + iii (modern paper, iii is pastedown): 1-11⁸ + 12⁸ (2 and 7 singletons) + 13⁸ + 14⁸ (2 and 7 singletons) + 15⁸ (3 and 6 singletons) + 16-19⁸ + 20⁶+ 21-23⁸ + 24⁶ (2 and 5 singletons).|Foliation: Two sets of modern foliation in pencil: in lower right corner (1-71; 73-186, skipping folios 7 and 163); in upper right corner (2-9; 17; 25; 30; 33; 40; 45; 50; 55; 59-60; 65; 70-71; 73;75; 80-81; 89; 95; 97-100; 105; 113; 120; 130; 135; 140; 145; 153; 155; 159; 160; 165; 167; 170; 175; 180; 183; 185-188.). The description follows the modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner, with missing foliation supplied by cataloger.|Signatures: Quires signed 1-24 in pencil in lower left corner on the recto of first folio of each gathering beginning with the first quire.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchwords to the right of center or at center on folios 8v, 16v, 24v, 32v, 40v, 48v, 56v, 64v, 72v, 80v, 96v, 104v, 112v, 120v, 136v, 144v, 152v, 158v, 166v, 174v, 182v.|Layout: Written in 28 long lines, above top line. Ruled in drypoint, with full-length double vertical bounding lines. Pricking marks visible in inner and lower margins in most quires, in outer margins in a few quires.|Script: Written by multiple, very similar hands in Gothica Textualis.|Decoration: 2- to 7-line initials in red, flourished in either red or brown throughout; a 5-line initial L in turquoise flourished in red on folio 34v; 1- to 2-line initials in turquoise flourished in red on folio 130v; 1-line initials in plain red throughout; sentence initials highlighted in red; some rubrics in red.|Binding: Modern. Bound in parchment over thick paper boards by Sangorski & Sutcliffe, London. Binder's stamp on the upper left corner of the verso of the first front flyleaf. Endbands in cream, yellow and light red.|Origin: Probably written in England or France around 1200.|Former shelfmark: MS Y21|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS D3|In good condition except for damage to the outer corners of the first two leaves and the excision to the last leaf. Recto of the first leaf is soiled and has an impression in the lower half from rusty metal, perhaps an older fastening. Lower outer corner of folio 73 and lower margin of folio 98 are torn, with no loss of text. Parchment defects throughout, ranging from medium-size holes to cuts and knife wounds. Evidence of early repairs on parchment in a series of leaves; most notably the last leaf whose lower third which was excised? (with one or two lines of text lost) was mended with a parchment patch. Parchment repairs by sewing on folios 65 and 122. Unevenly trimmed especially in the second half of the manuscript and especially on the head. Minor bookworm damage throughout. Minor ink spill in the lower half of folio 75v. Some marginal annotations by the scribes; corrections, including use of technical signs such as obelus, quotation signs, and Nota Bene, in a darker ink by a contemporary hand. Few interlinear corrections. Overwriting in a few places.|Hebrew numbering is Psalm 119.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. From the collection of Sir Thomas Phillipps (Phillipps MS 3596). It is inscribed "Phillipps MS 3596" in ink in the lower margin of folio 1r, now partly effaced. Listed as no. 3596 under "Miscellanea" in The Phillipps Manuscripts. After his death, Sir Thomas Phillipps's library was inherited by Katherine Fenwick, his daughter, and later passed on to Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick, his grandson. The manuscript was sold by Thomas FitzRoy Fenwick in a 1903 Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge auction to J. & J. Leighton, booksellers and bookbinders in London. In 1910, it was purchased from J. & J. Leighton by Libreria Antiquaria T. De Marinis.

note: Title from the title page on folio 2r.|Manuscript codex|Collation: ii (modern paper, i is pastedown) + 52 (parchment and modern paper) + ii (modern paper, ii is pastedown): 1² + 1 leaf added before 1 + 2⁴ (wants 1, 3) + 3⁴ (wants 1) + 4⁴ (wants 1) + 5⁴ (wants 1, 2) + 6-8⁴ + 9⁴ (wants 1) + 10-15⁴. Only the first leaf is parchment.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (3-52).|Watermarks: Partial watermarks present on the upper part of leaves near inner margins (unidentified).|Layout: All paper leaves have a double lined full frame in ink, inside which the parchment cuttings are pasted according to no apparent order or layout.|Script: Written by multiple hands. Writing is visible only on a few cuttings; both Gothic rotunda and Humanistic bookhand are present.|Decoration: Initials of different sizes representing several different styles, including historiated and anthropomorphic initials as well as those with foliate and penwork decorations. About half have either a gold background or another decoration in gold; parts of border decorations of different styles.|Music: The fragment that constitutes the first folio of the codex as well as the cuttings pasted on folios 3r, 4r, 14r, 18r, 37r, 38r, 39r, 47r, 48r and 52r contain music, mostly square notation on four-line staff in red.|Binding: Modern. Bound in parchment and paste paper in light brown patterns over paper boards. Sewn endbands in light blue and red. Paper slipcase covered with the same paste paper. The slipcase is lightly soiled, deformed and damaged around the corners. Two paper labels adhered to head and tail of spine. A paper label adhered to upper part of slipcase. The paper labels at head of spine and on the slipcase bear the same short title and are of similar design.|Origin: Probably put together in the first half of the nineteenth century in Italy. Manuscript cuttings, presumably all also of Italian origin, are dated to the fourteenth to sixteenth centuries.|Former shelfmark: MS Y35|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS D9|In relatively good condition except for missing leaves and missing manuscript cuttings from the existing leaves. Modern annotations in pencil, mostly for the purpose of numbering or categorizing the cuttings, throughout.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. Possible bookseller marks in pencil in upper left corner of front pastedown: "ycx / 325." Octagonal paper label with a blue border and a handwritten number "3463" adhered to tail of spine.

physical_description: Extent: 10 leaves : parchment ; 263 x 187 (175 x 130) mm bound to 273 x 198 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript gatherings|Collation: i (paper, pastedown) + 10 (parchment) + i (paper, pastedown): 1² (wants 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8) + 2⁸. Several quires missing at the beginning and the end.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (2, 7, 9-16), inserted to signal the former state of the gatherings. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Catchwords: Horizontal catchword in lower right on folio 10v.|Layout: Written in two columns of 34 lines, below top line. Ruled in lead, with full-length vertical bounding lines for both columns.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica textualis libraria.|Decoration: 2- to 3-line initials in alternating red and blue with penwork in the opposite color at the beginning of each chapter; chapter numbers in Roman numerals preceded with a pilcrow in red and blue; running titles in red and blue in upper margins (MA / TE to indicate Matthew). The blue (or, silver?) is almost completely faded in all of the leaves, now visible to the naked eye as pale gray.|Binding: Modern. Conservation pamphlet with cream paper covers tacketed to the bookblock.|Origin: Probably written in northern France in the second half of thirteenth century.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS D40|Related shelfmark: Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Département des manuscrits, français 899|The passages in MS D40 correspond very closely to the copy of the Old French Bible found in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Département des manuscrits, français 899, folios 271vb-272vb; 276ra-276vb and 277vb-288va.|In moderate condition despite wear and tear due to previous use as part of a binding of another book. All leaves are soiled and damaged with holes and tears, with loss of text. The outer edges and corners of folios 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10 are cut off in different shapes. Evidence of former repairs; tears were mended and the gatherings were reinforced by adhering paper strips to the spine-folds of the innermost leaves of the first quire and the innermost and the outermost leaves of the second quire.|History of the manuscript is unknown.

ST3 [?]" in ink.|Origin: Probably written in Germany and completed in 1456: "Anno d[omi]ni 1456"-- colophon, folio 9rb.|Former shelfmark: MS Y139|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS D38|In good condition except for ink smears on a few leaves. An encircled number "102" and other annotations (now erased) in pencil in lower half of front pastedown. Inscribed "bull 19/264" in pencil in lower left corner of back pastedown, presumably a reference to the watermark found in the manuscript.

physical_description: Extent: 54 leaves : paper ; 213 x 143 (143 x 100-105) mm bound to 202 x 180 mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript codex|Collation: 54 (paper): 1¹² + 2¹⁴ + 3²⁸. The quire structure is unusual; there are two gatherings of different sizes nesting in both the second and third gatherings. The conjugate leaves are as follows: 1-12; 2-11; 3-10; 4-9; 5-8; 6-7; 13-26; 14-25; 15-18; 16-17; 19-24; 20-23; 21-22; 27-54; 28-53; 29-36; 30-35; 31-34; 32-33; 37-52; 38-51; 39-50; 40-49; 41-48; 42-47; 43-46; 44-45.|Foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right corner (1-54).|Signatures: Leaves signed 1-6 (folios 1-6); 1-9 (folios 13-21); 1-6 (folios 27-32); 1-8 (folios 37-44) in lower right corner of the recto of the leaves.|Watermarks: Watermarks present (unidentified).|Layout: Written in 31-32 long lines, above top line. Frame ruled in lead.|Script: Written by at least two hands in Anglicana formata.|Decoration: 3-line initial T in plain red on folio 1r; initials highlighted in red on folio 1r; phrases underlined in red on folio 1r; 1- to 3-line spaces left for initials in the rest of the manuscript.|Binding: Contemporary. Parchment case binding attached with primary tackets made from cords. Binding is worn, with parchment cover damaged.|Origin: Probably written shortly after 1459 in England.|Former shelfmark: MS P613|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS C299|Related shelfmark: Cambridge, Cambridge University Library, Dd.5.23|Related shelfmark: Oxford, University of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. lat. misc. e. 103|MS C299 contains a copy of the "Kingmill's Course on Conveyancing" found in Cambridge, Cambridge University Library, Dd.5.23 (see John H. Baker, A Catalogue of English Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library. Woodbridge: Boydell, 1996. pp. 33-34 on the Cambridge manuscript and other manuscript copies of the text). MS C299 is closely related to Oxford, University of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. lat. misc. e. 103, especially until MS C299, folio 47r which corresponds to MS. lat. misc. e. 103, folio 60r. From 47v, the text remains similar but is organized differently in the two manuscripts. The final section of each manuscript contains different passages that are not found in the other. The contents of the Kansas and Oxford manuscripts were compared by Dr. Matthew Holford, Bodleian Library, University of Oxford, United Kingdom, 2022.|In good condition despite rodent damage along the spine and on the inner margin (no loss of text). Deckle edges visible. Nota and paragraph signs and few contemporary marginal additions and corrections. Short texts (unidentified) as well as pen trials and a mathematical calculation in contemporary hands on the inside of the covers.|The manuscript comes from the renowned Tresham Brudenell Library at Deene Park, England and very likely was part of the collection of Sir Thomas Tresham. It was purchased by Bernard M. Rosenthal at the 1967 Sotheby's auction. Possible bookseller marks in pencil on the inside of the front cover, perhaps by different hands: "XVI.a.19," "D.6.12" and "526."

title_as_recorded: Compendium historiae in genealogia Christi, incomplete /
subject_as_recorded: Jesus Christ--Genealogy--Early works to 1800|Jesus Christ--Family--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Medieval|Manuscripts, Medieval--Kansas--Lawrence|Manuscripts, Latin
subject_label: Jesus Christ;Genealogy;Early works|Jesus Christ;Families;Early works|Manuscripts, Medieval|Manuscripts, Medieval;Kansas--Lawrence|Manuscripts, Latin
physical_description: Extent: 1 bifolium : parchment, illuminations, portraits, genealogical tables ; 338 x 245 (280 x 205) mm
note: Title devised by cataloger.|Manuscript leaves|Collation: 2 leaves (parchment): based on the contents, the two conjoint leaves possibly formed the middle bifolium of a ternion or folios 3 and 6 of a quaternion.|Foliation: Unfoliated. Foliation supplied by cataloger.|Layout: Written in one to two columns of 55 lines. Pricking marks are visible on outer edges of both folios but there is no evidence of ruling except for full-length vertical bounding lines in ink.|Script: Written by a single hand in Gothica textualis.|Decoration: Vertical diagrams with double-lined roundels connected with double lines throughout, drawn in ink and colored in bright green, dark blue, bright orange, pink, light red and light yellow. Full-length vertical bounding lines on the outer edges of each folio, also drawn and colored in the same manner. Four portraits over the roundels of Jesse (label: "Ysay [ve]l Yesse"), Achitob (label: "Achitob"), Abigail (label: "Abigail") and an unidentified bearded man (label: "p[ro]phete") as well as two portraits inside the roundels labelled as David and Solomon on folio 1r; four portraits over the roundels of Achim (label: "Achimas"), Abdon (label: "Abdo"), Rehoboam (label: "Roboam") and Jeroboam I (label: "Ieroboam") and a crown over the roundel of Ben-Hadad I (label: "Be[n]nadab") on folio 1v; four portraits over the roundels of Antipater (label: "Antipat[er]"), Caesar Augustus (label: "Octavianus Aug[us]tus Cesar"), Hismeria (label: "Hism[er]ia") and Anne (label: "Anna") as well as three connected scenes from the life of Christ: birth, infancy and crucifixion on folio 2r; a portrait of God (label: "Deus") and a scene depicting Moses receiving the law from God (labels: "Moyses" and "lex") on folio 2v. 22 roundels with text on folio 1r, 31 on folio 1v, 59 on folio 2r and 42 on folio 2v. 1- to 2-line initials in red; sentence initials highlighted in red; paragraph marks in the same ink as the text; rubrication in red.|Binding: Unbound.|Origin: Probably written somewhere in Central Europe, perhaps in Austria around 1300.|Shelfmark: Lawrence, University of Kansas, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, MS 9:2.29|In fragile condition, with damage especially to the outer edges of the leaves and creases in the center-fold. Signs of early repairs on folio 2. The manuscript is soiled especially on folio 2r. Interlinear and marginal annotations by a later (fifteenth century?) hand throughout.|The manuscript contains roughly the narrative of the fourth age, beginning with David (folios 1r-1v) and the sixth age, beginning with the birth of Christ (folio 2r). The beginning of the text as well as the text for the fifth age are missing. The order of the passages and the decorative program are markedly different than other known manuscript copies of the Compendium historiae in genealogia Christi.|Early history of the manuscript is unknown. The manuscript was purchased by Bernard M. Rosenthal at the 1973 Sotheby's auction.
